reviewText:
Bioshock Infinite is quite different than the other Bioshock games because of what‚Äôs excluded. Gone is the city of Rapture. Gone is Jack, the protagonist. Gone is Andrew Ryan, the main villain in Rapture. Gone are Big Daddies and the Little Sisters. What‚Äôs new is the city of Columbia in the year 1912, a city that seceded from the United States because of its ideals and feelings of superiority.

While Rapture was a city underwater, Columbia is a city floating on top of the clouds and is beautiful on the outside, ugly on the inside. It is a gorgeously rendered, lively city with townsfolk realistically having fun at a local fair, children playing with each other, birds chirping, and lots of propaganda. The propaganda is what shows the ugly side of Columbia: racism, extreme views based on religion, and very nationalistic beliefs. It promotes white supremacy in ways that would remind people of America‚Äôs ugly past and degrades working class people. Most shooters do not do such a great job in rendering a city so well with great art direction. It feels so brilliantly directed that it feels like it was directed by an experienced movie director.

The protagonist is Booker DeWitt, a private eye who has a shady and a mysterious past. His job is to find a girl named Elizabeth, who is in the possession of a gigantic bird known as Songbird. Throughout the story, you will frequently hear the quote ‚Äúwipe away the debt.‚Äù This seems to relate to DeWitt‚Äôs purpose of finding Elizabeth. The game gets better after finding Elizabeth, as she is free from the Songbird and tries to help DeWitt in more ways than one. He is up against Zachary Comstock, who is known as the prophet of Columbia. He is the Andrew Ryan of Columbia and frequently calls DeWitt a ‚Äúfalse shepherd.‚Äù He influences the citizens to hate and stop DeWitt in any way possible.

Columbia is a more open setting than Rapture, so it‚Äôs not as linear as the first two Bioshock games. The weapons, vigors, and related upgrades largely work the same as the weapons, plasmids and related upgrades in Rapture, but with different names. Vigors work like plasmids, but they require you to drink from well-designed bottles to obtain those powers. You will have to learn how to use vigors strategically during battles with the local police, the rebellious people of Columbia, and Comstock‚Äôs large, magical enemies. The wide open districts in Columbia mean that combat feels like it is in wide open arenas. What is part of some of these districts is the skylines, tracks that look like roller coasters allowing you to use your Skyhook, a mechanical gauntlet that can be used to melee some enemies, but is not useful against the more powerful enemies. The Skyhook is also good for navigating to rooftops and other hard to reach areas. You can also use the skylines to drop down and knock out enemies instantly.

The larger enemies in the game are quite interesting, including a motorized patriot. The motorized patriot is an imitation of former U.S. president George Washington. The patriot carries a crank gun, a Gatling gun that can tear you to shreds in seconds. Another large enemy is the Handyman, a pumped up version of the Big Daddy with a lot of height. Some vigors work well against some enemies, but other enemies are immune to them. One vigor, the murder of crows, throws a group of crows at an enemy in its radius, causing lots of distractions and allows you to fire at them with conventional firearms without retaliation for several seconds. However, there are some enemies that are immune to the murder of crows. I remember fighting a Zealot, a Comstock supporter who carries a coffin on his back and can turn into crows to defend himself. I realized that he was immune to the murder of crows, so I had to turn to other vigors such as shock jockey or the devil‚Äôs kiss while being careful with my salt level. Salt works like eve did in the previous Bioshock games. In essence, you have to know each enemy‚Äôs strengths and weaknesses against vigors.

Elizabeth is a blessing during combat. She doesn‚Äôt get in your way and can help replenish ammo, health, and salts in the heat of battle. Her AI is surprisingly superb, as she knows exactly when to stay away from you. She may get in your way when you are trying to walk through a doorway, but that is nothing more than an annoyance. She can help open tears so that you can access weapons, ammo, turrets, and a motorized patriot. You can open a tear of a motorized patriot to shoot it out with a motorized patriot who is trying to bring you down. Tears appear to be alternate grey looking worlds that can be only opened by her. The tears are crucial to survival and sometimes lead to alternate worlds. It looks to me like tears make the story contrived since they seem to always favor you when you are in a desperate combat situation. Therefore, the combats with the tears seem staged, but that‚Äôs only a minor complaint.

The ending of the story seems to include a lot of emotion and drama that some people may not even understand it fully. However, the graphics are rendered beautifully. The DLCs are a continuation of Bioshock Infinite and include Burial at Sea: Episode 1 and Episode 2. They bring you back to the city of Rapture and get into the connection between the city of Rapture and the city of Columbia. It also touches upon the connection between Comstock and Ryan. I recommend playing Episode 1 before playing Episode 2. I think Episode 2 has a better plot than Episode 1 and tells a better story about Rapture and its connections to Columbia. Interestingly, you will play Elizabeth in Episode 2, as it explains Elizabeth‚Äôs complex life in both Rapture and Columbia. It also emphasizes stealth for Elizabeth, who seems to be too weak for combat against Rapture‚Äôs splicers and Columbia‚Äôs Vox Populi.

Bioshock Infinite is a fabulous game in terms of gameplay and art direction. The combat is definitely worth your participation as it requires lots of strategy with conventional firearms and various vigors against Comstock‚Äôs diverse citizenry. I highly recommend this superb game to any gamer.

My Score: 9.5/10

reviewText:
We All Live in a Yellow Submarine


The Good

- really good looking.

- tries to deal with large themes

- the meta statement was neat (the idea of how when we experience a story, or game in this case, it will always be the same despite some variables)

- I think the music could be objectively good (I liked the Beach Boys cover), but it didn't stand out as much to me as much the first Bioshock. I will leave it in the good pile though.

Questionable

- It handles its grand themes clumsily and with a heavy hand. They decide to deal with racism by using the shock value of the public pelting (which then concludes with some gruesomely brutal killing, because that means great narrative) and the statement over blind zeal is handled by a cartoon villain.

- I think it tried a bit too hard to ride on the original Bioshock's coattails. Vigors are shoehorned in, sound bites are recycled, and Gears are watered down tonics.

- The tears and infinite universes kind of seem like a wasted opportunity. Gameplay wise opening up tears is the same thing as picking up ammo, health, weapons etc. Yeah she can pull out a samurai or neat looking turret, but it only looks cool there is no added or changed value by it coming from a tear. It's not a bad mechanic but it is a very cliche one with a new coat of paint, and I feel like Infinite really could have broken new ground with it.

- So I know at some point they stated they wanted the many worlds thing to rival interpretation in film and bring it to video games as something unique. However the thing is, interpretation has already been in video games for a long time. Depending on how deeply you want to look into games, anything can be interpreted. Some games would be more abstract or cryptic about it (Another World, or even the Super Mario series), but interpretation and analysis is there.

-Overall gameplay. Very cliche and weak. You don't actually have to think about much, just splash around some vigors and shoot. Some enemies can really soak up damage, but they are all pretty lazy and just charge at you. The guns are all very basic with some stats differing between pairs. The shield mechanic is also another crutch that feels like they were really trying to appeal to a wider audience...

Oh wait. I get it now.

Bioshock Infinite is probably one of the best shooters out there if you only compare it to modern shooters. It is meant to be the prize horse of shooters like Call of Duty rather than System Shock or Deus Ex. I was expecting more in terms RPG elements or narrative, but that was not Infinite's goal.

As a sequel? I am not sure if it will measure to what you are wanting: some of the mechanics are polished while others were watered down.

On its own? Bioshock Infinite is a great action game that offers polished and accessible combat in a vivid and interesting setting . On top of that it gives a nice little overview of some heavy themes and tries to focus a bit on narrative. It is closer to Call of Duty than Fallout 3 compared to its predecessors.

So, if you don't really like to play video games or tend to play games that aren't known for their story, then think of this as Ringo introducing you to the Beatles. From here you can try your hand at games that offer different experiences like: more complicated/challenging shooting, different activities besides shooting (like hacking, stealing, exploring), more focus on strictly storytelling (like point and clicks), and maybe games that are a bit more abstract or pretentious.

If you are pretty used to video games, especially mondern shooters, this game will cover familiar ground and might not wow you. If you are a snob? this might be a lukewarm experience for you.

reviewText:
Bring us the girl. Wipe away the debt.

Bioshock Infinite is a fantastic First-Person shooter in the sense that it has fun gameplay with a strong narrative behind it,driving the game forward. You take the role as Booker Dewitt, a man we know nothing about, and you are asked to find the girl and if done so, you will wipe away the debt. The story seems to be simple but as the game goes along, it gets more intricate and by the end it had me in awe. Even the second time around. The dialogue and voice acting is some of the best I have ever heard (Troy Baker is God) and it really helps immerse the player into the world of Columbia. I found myself finding and playing every single voxophone, small voice recordings of characters, because I loved the side/back stories behind all the characters introduced.

Elizabeth, the girl, is a strong female lead for the game because she is very likable. She has some great AI mechanics which do not hinder the fastpaced gameplay but instead make it more interesting and fun as Elizabeth throws whatever she can at your aid to benefit you. The gun mechanics feel very smooth and the added Vigors allow more variety to be in play from shock powers" to "calling in a swarm of crows" powers and it really helps make the game so much more fun. Another aspect which makes the game so much fun is introduced a little into the game and it is the skylines. The skylines allow the player to ride above the ground and land off and attack or flank enemies from all over the area.

The main story clocked in for me at about nine hours which I think was the perfect length for a game like this. I played the game originally when it released on the Playstation 3 and I enjoyed the feel of the game a whole lot more on PC. It runs better

reviewText:
This is my fave Bioshock game,  better characters that I actually felt like I cared about,  I like that the characters talk to each other and have banter, previous games only chatter you'd get is from audio logs or a radio message telling you what to do next, environment is visually gorgeous and has an immersive if somewhat convoluted story.
I like Columbia much more than I do Rapture,  swinging around on sky hooks and using a sky hook to swoop down and kill an enemy. I was starting to get sick of Rapture and am glad this game has a different setting.

The game gives the illusion of a vast expansive sky city, it does not have the stuffy claustrophobic feel of the underwater city Rapture. In Columbia you just want to soar and swoop at every chance you can. Though it does make my stomach churn at times using a sky rail is almost like riding a roller coaster.

Elizabeth is an interesting character though at first she reminded me a lot of a Disney princess, the way she moves, expressions in an over exagerated disney princess way, she's almost a rip off of Belle from Beauty and the Beast in how she looks, she has same hairstyle, big over large eyes.

You have a variety of ways to kill enemies you can ask elizabeth to open a tear so you can have more cover, a hook for swinging off, medical kits, guns, turrets, though that is limited as you can only have 1 tear open and active at a time.

But the game is not without frustration.

You can only carry 2 guns at a time which is very limiting, though you can swap 1 gun you are carrying for a gun that's on the ground, you can never carry more than 2 at a time.

Vigors are often the most fun and versatile ways to kill which are the replacement for plasmids but are much more limited in their use as you can't carry salts on you, you seem to run out of salts way too quickly though  (salts are the blue energy metre simular to eve) to replenish salts you have to find some sort of drink or a bottle of salts. Usually there are salts nearby or Elizabeth will find and toss you some.

You can't carry first aid kits either but you have a energy shield which is better, you don't lose health unless your shield is fully depleted and if that happens you can just hide till it replenishes.

But even so I found the battles more fast paced and enjoyable than the previous Bioshocks.

I dislike most  that there is only auto save and you can't save your game when you want. I wanted to stop playing but it said my last auto save was 10 minutes ago, so had to keep playing for 10 more minutes to get the next checkpoint. It makes it so I have to replay again if I just want to quit playing. The most annoying thing about the game. I had to leave the game running when I wanted a break as my last checkpoint save was half an hour ago, auto saves should be at least every 10 minutes.

There is no hacking, I miss that.
The only thing that is a tiny bit like it is that Elizabeth can pick locks for you, but there is no mini game associated with it.

To sumarise it overall the game is better in some ways than the other Bioshocks but also worse in other aspects.

The story overall is rather freaky, tragic and messes with your head, I did a lot of reading about it to understand the story fully. But I better not say anything else as I don't want to spoil it for those who have not played and completed the game.

Mostly though it feels enjoyable, fun, scary in some ways and exciting. Though unlike others I would not got so far as to say it's one of the best games I've played. Almost would rate it an 8, but there is too many negatives that the game should not have, it does not deserve more than 7/10.

reviewText:
The scope and ambition of Bioshock: Infinite is in itself difficult to fully take in, but it‚Äôs in seeing this ambition conceptualized in such astounding fashion that causes it to become almost exhausting to try and appreciate the vast amount of layers laid in such an intricate pattern required to make it what it is.

It‚Äôs the rarest of occasions where the incalculable expectations heaped upon it are not only met, but exceeded, in ways I wouldn‚Äôt have anticipated despite my own rabid hopes for what the game might be. It‚Äôs an experience that‚Äôs both familiar yet defiantly willing to take risks in its attempts to outdo its predecessors, firmly steeped in its own heritage but only so much as it can be used to further itself into something even more remarkable, constantly pushing itself to new heights despite the possible catastrophe that could result. And it pays off. What Irrational Games has achieved is unprecedented, deserving of commendation and once again resetting the bar that the original Bioshock did so many years ago. It‚Äôs truly something to behold.

The setup to Infinite‚Äôs plot is likely the sole moment that can be easily explained, materializing with the words that have become so familiar by now but adopt a larger meaning in their greater narrative context: ‚Äúbring us the girl, and wipe away the debt‚Äù. You are Booker Dewitt, a man on his last line of hope in removing himself out from under the hand of some very dangerous people.

And this is where Infinite forgoes any semblance of simplicity or predictability, literally ascending into the floating city of Columbia and a far more complex, complicated narrative that all but demands repeated playthroughs to truly understand. Columbia is itself a fascinating world to explore, for reasons Rapture never was or could be. It‚Äôs a living, breathing city that unravels at a deliberately slow pace, dropping breadcrumbs for you every step of the way but never exposing itself enough to have you see the full picture and become disinterested.

The city feels real, for as fantastical and impossible the existence of a floating city seems; a gorgeous, fully realized environment dripping in early American history and architecture that comes to life in an artistically arresting display of color and visual fidelity. The constant dissimilarity between the beautiful areas you explore and the horrifically grotesque violence that takes place within them creates a sort of twisted beauty that never wavers or deteriorates into mindless gore.

In many ways Columbia exists almost to entirely contradict rapture. It's a city floating in the sky, brought up by a fiercely communal, religious figure head that seeks not to eradicate law and God but embrace the ideals of a warped version of Christianity created in his own image. You arrive here not after the dust has settled and the city has fallen, but at the cusp of a viscous civil war that is nearing its boiler point, waiting for you to drop the match and light the flames.

In the wake of the many firefights and incredible scenes of destruction that litter the path to Infinite‚Äôs shocking finish, it was often the quiet moments that made me appreciate Columbia the most for giving me something Rapture never did. Without the constant fear of being attacked or an oppressive atmosphere weighing you down, Infinite is allowed to show its humanity. Seeing the city the full of life gives a sense of place on a level I've rarely witnessed. Kids running in the streets, venders attempting to sell you their wares; it all serves to establish this robust society before its descent into madness, something often lost in a medium seemingly obsessed with sterile, dystopian wastelands.

At the center of this is Elizabeth, the girl previously referred to who immediately upon her introduction becomes far more than the mere bartering tool that you set out for. She‚Äôs a character without the flimsy mirage of personality drawn up to hide a lack of depth, or a throwaway damsel that only serves to burden you down. She‚Äôs a person; naive, curious, independent, and the one you come to rely on throughout the game almost more so than she does you.

The relationship between her and Booker is the grounding force for a narrative that often feels as if it could spin wildly out of control at any moment, but stays firmly on course throughout every path it goes down, the culmination for which is only describable as utterly insane and brilliant.

With all it attempts, there are certainly a handful of threads which never get the closure or development they deserve, most prominently that of the deeply rooted racism of Columbia and the rebel for of the Vox Populi that has sprung up as a result. It‚Äôs one of the most compelling subplots in the game, though unfortunately has little time to be expanded upon and is mostly a means to a very violent end. Ultimately it‚Äôs almost understandable, as there is hardly room for Infinite‚Äôs larger narrative to exist in, let alone as many subplots as it has also managed to fit in alongside it.

Though the shooting in Bioshock has never been a problem (quite the opposite, it‚Äôs one of the most intelligent and mechanically sophisticated shooters ever made), Infinite is unquestionably smoother in every aspect. It‚Äôs a faster, tighter, streamlined game that smartly ejects portions of past games to allow space for its new mechanics to coexist. The core of combat is in many ways the same as it has always been, with mostly names being swapped to reflect the change in local, but otherwise preserving the strongest aspects of Bioshock‚Äôs combat while expanding upon them in intelligent ways that further the tactical depth of each encounter.

The skyhook provides one of the biggest changes to the formula, allowing for a level of verticality the series has never had, as you zip along rails through huge levels which require you take note of the new speed with which you can traverse levels and the vantage points now accessible. It requires a complete rethinking of how fights are approached, and gives the player the tools to take on larger numbers of enemies that in turn are also granted access to these new tools, and make full use of them in their pursuit to take you down.

Vigors, Infinite‚Äôs replacement for plasmids, offer the same superhuman element as before but now in a much more focused and deliberate manner. Different abilities can be combined into more effective weapons, from electrocuting a murder of crows, to creating exploding enemies by setting them ablaze and then charging into them. It‚Äôs a logical evolution of the series‚Äôs most unique mechanic, and that only grows further as you come to learn the various combos hidden in the already powerful abilities.

The switch to only being able to carry two weapons at a time at first felt like a disadvantage, but effectively worked in making me pay more attention to my surroundings and be more active in choosing which weapons to use and where to find new ones. It ensured I was constantly moving and engaged in the combat, as different weapons were often noticeably more effective against different enemy types and I was rarely given the luxury of having them all nearby. Coupled with the smoother aiming and ability to sprint and aim down the sights fundamentally altered how I played, and by and large made for a more compelling experience.

Bioshock: Infinite is a stunning achievement; bold, refined, innovative, and constantly stimulating. It‚Äôs a game that never falters in its vision, fearful of how easy it would be to have it all crumble upon the weight of its own aspirations, confident in its ability to deliver something awe-inspiring. There are few experiences more worth your time, and leave you with as much to think about.

reviewText: Bioshock Infinite is the third in the Bioshock trilogy, bringing to a close the story of our Protagonist. A Steampunk-styled, dystopian alternate universe; However, instead of traveling to city at the bottom of the ocean, you are transported to a sky city where everything is Heaven-flavored, that is until it all goes to Hell. Fast. I have to admit, I sort of fell in love with the series after a short time playing the very first Bioshock. I found myself wanting to immerse myself in the story and learn all I could, while trying to survive not only the hidden things lurking around corners, but the scattered people who seem to have gone completely insane. This Bioshock was different. In this, the people of the sky city are told by their rulers, whom they almost seem to worship, that you are The Marked One, who must be killed. So instead of encountering people who are completely insane, you are chased, cornered, and attacked by people of thinly veiled sanity, from a once seemingly utopian society. I would recommend this game, as well as the entire Trilogy, as it was fun, exciting, and worth at least a playthough.

reviewText:
BioShock Infinite... one of the most critically overhyped game, is THE biggest disappointment of the year for me by FAR.

The game starts out very, very strong by showing you our character, Booker DeWitt and explaining why he has the mission to find a mysterious girl by the name of Elizabeth, and so is sent to the world of Columbia, a colossal city in atop the sky. I say it starts out strong is because it wastes no time in immersing you into what you immediately see a vast city filled with life and soul, but it quickly drops after you're introduced to the actual game.

~Visuals
Right at the very beginning, you can see how beautiful the game is. With vibrant colors and clean textures for most of what you see. Although some items thruought the world of Columbia have muddy textures and just things that look downright lazy, it's essentially a nitpick when you see what the real focus of the game is - however those items are still present and detract from the overall ambiance. Enemy models and the such are varied throught the game when it switches the standard Columbia militia for members of a cult organization to supernatural entities.

~Sound
Not much to say for this game. The game has a few ambiance setting melodies throughout to keep the mood running the way the situation calls for it, though generally you won't notice the music running in the background at all, there aren't any real unforgettable scores other than Elizabeth's Theme. The rest of the game does a fairly well job of relaying how guns work, the enemies yelling in the background mocking you, the distance of their gunshots, etc. My best mention sound wise, is the soundwork for Songbird - it is genually as creepy as the Big Daddy's cry in the original BioShock.

~Gameplay
Sadly though, this is actually where the game faulters. The game quickly starts you on a shooting romp that is seemingly never ending without much variation. From the very first gunfight you have in the game, the only things that change is when you get more weapons, more vigors and Elizabeth starts using her powers, most of which, with the exception of Elizabeth, do nothing to improve the base gameplay the game has to offer.

You can use vigors (very similar to that of BioShock 1 & 2, but in here, you're better off going the gung ho" way as the vigors on this game are pretty underpowered

reviewText: As a gamer, I was of course excited to hear about another BioShock title in development, but I was skeptical towards its potential success. Upon release, BioShock: Infinite was praised with positive reviews that I personally noted, but they did not alter my skepticism. How wrong was I? Completely. Totally. Utterly. Rarely does any medium of entertainment--from books to movies---challenge my perceptions or affect my emotions. BioShock: Infinite did and I'm not sure why. The game is a virtual rollercoaster ride that mixes strong dramatization, story, characters and new gameplay mechanics that build up another one of Ken Levine's twisted dystopias. The game also offers one of the most compelling non-playable characters (NPCs) to date that will ultimately lure you into the world of BioShock. The game is beautiful, varied and philosophical in its representation. BioShock: Infinite has displaced the Mass Effect series as my all-time favorite game which is a statement unto itself considering the length of one game versus a trilogy. reviewText:
BioShock Infinite is a splendid experience: From its intriguing, beautifully crafted opening with its ferly images and haunting music - to its amazing finale: I find this to be a memorable work of art.

It tells a very fantastical tale, laden with philosophy and other famous human labyrinths. It begins mysteriously and soon shows a wondrous world of a colorful fancy; yet, very soon once again, this lovely world reveals its sad, painful secrets; and then, as we get to know the characters and their motivations, their hopes, their fears, we find a tale that is touched by sorrow and longings for redemption or freedom. But there is something more. Its secrets are unveiled eventually, yet there is still much that is left to the player all shattered, and which much be put back together.

When the world is torn by hands that touch other worlds, other times, this tale begins to tear the heart too, ever so slowly. In the end, the lives here woven together, the truths gleaned or disinterred, the frailty of it all - lead to an astonishing epilogue that, for all its perplexities and sorrows, all its aesthetic or poetic beauties and its dark paradoxes, I found very splendid.

There are certain scenes, meetings, conversations, revelations, atmospheres, pains, smiles, sounds, tunes, compositions of horizon and voice, which alone are of great artistic beauty. And, as a whole, with its superb visual design, its excellent soundtrack, its interesting world, its plot with so much fantasy and so much humanity, its dramatic might, and its characters, or some characters I came to care about, BioShock Infinite is a very intense experience whose impressions may well be indelible.

reviewText:
INTRODUCTION:
Bioshock Infinite is the third installment to the popular Bioshock series. Set in a city in the sky as opposed to the city underwater, this game features a revamped combat mechanic featuring Sky-lines rails and and a new AI companion, all the while, retaining some of the old features of the previous games.

You play as Booker DeWitt, a former 7th Cavalry soldier turned Pinkerton who was tasked by unknown individuals to recover a girl, Elizabeth, from the floating city of Colombia. A simple recovery mission quickly turns sour when the girl you have to take turns out to be a very important figure head.

PROS:
+ Story: -Needless to say, the one primary factor that drives the Bioshock games is they are narrative-driven. This game delivers a very compelling, interesting and immersive story that makes you want to know more about the city and world of Colombia.

+ Graphics: -Stunning visuals and magnificent world design makes Bioshock infinite one of the prettiest games of the franchise. Breathtaking scenery, beautiful texture quality and character designs makes the world alive.

+ Elizabeth: -I normally frown at escort missions, specially if the AI is poorly programed for, but Bioshock Infinite (despite being an escort mission start to finish) got past that  by introducing an companion AI who is helpful and doesn‚Äôt get in the way. She assists the player through support roles providing money, ammo, and regenerative potions all throughout the game. She's not the revolutionary AI companion that everyone was excited about, but she's the closest one we have.

+ Optimization: -Was optimized enough for the PC to allow even mid-range desktops or laptops to play the game in relatively high or medium-high settings.

CONS:
- Combat: -Retains the fun and high paced combat with guns and magic of the previous titles BUT seriously fails due to the poor decision of limiting the player with only TWO weapons carry limit which does not live up to the previous games who had several weapons at the player's disposal. Too many: (1) Kill Bad Guys, (2) Elizabeth Opens Door, Repeat step one, sequences.

- Poor Antagonist (No Spoiler): -Explaining this is a bit hard without spoilers. We were introduced with a great antagonist by the name of Andrew Ryan in the first game but I can't help but feel that the new Antagonist, Comstock falls short. Anything more would be a spoiler. Now even the new Songbird creature (kinda like a buffed up Big Daddy) makes very, very limited appearances and its role in the whole story somewhat becomes pointless once you progress.

- No sense of Danger: -This has been an illness since the first game. Death in the Bioshock franchise is more of a minor inconvenience than an actual penalty. Vita-Chambers in the first and second Bioshock games made death pointless. This was carried over to Bioshock Infinite where the Vita-Chambers beeing replaced by Elizabeth reviving you every time you get incapacitated. This totally eliminates any sense of dread that you should be feeling in a high combat scenario.

CONCLUSION:
AN OVERALL GREAT GAME. Though it has its short comings, I would still recommend Bioshock Infinite to any fan of the franchise. It provides a satisfying narrative and introduces new characters that leave a lasting impact.

Although I would still RECOMMEND this game to NEW players in the Bioshock franchise, I think this is best appreciated by people who already gone through the first and second games.

reviewText: This series is more story than game at this point. I felt like I was shooting enemies just so I could earn the next bit of exposition at times. One of the criticisms leveled against the first Bioshock was the drop in quality during the third act, after the climax. Infinite attempts to address this by ending the base campaign right after the appropriate moment. Those unhappy with the ending are welcome to try the DLC, although I doubt anyone looking for a happy ending will be satisfied with that either. I like sad stories so of course I thoroughly enjoyed it. As always, the value here depends heavily on your expectations. I have to agree with zero punctuation on this one - it's not perfect, you can point out the flaws, but its way more ambitious than most anything else that came out in the same year, which makes it GOTY. Sad that it didn't make enough money to keep the devs in business. AAA games may have to take a rest until they find a business model.

reviewText: Coming from someone who's beaten this game about 3 or 4 times now, with having beaten it very recently, I can definitely give this game two thumbs up from me! BioShock Infinite serves as an excellent addition to the BioShock franchise and if I must say, has become my favorite game of the series. It's a game that has an excellent story, interesting and loveable characters, amazing settings, and more. With the previous two games having both taken place in the underwater city of Rapture, it's nice to see this game take a departure from there and instead, having it take place a completely brand new, different setting, which is the floating city of Columbia. I also enjoyed the game's soundtrack and as well, was taken in by the graphics of the game. It isn't the top of the line realism graphics, but graphics that I find to be quite beautiful. And then there's Elizabeth! She has to be one of my favorite companions of any game. I could honestly go on about her for ages, but in short, she's a character I easily grew to love and who has a very interesting personality, as well as backstory. As well, a companion who is actually seems real as opposed to a not so smart AI. One of my favorite things of this game though is that the city of Columbia as a whole and it's people, as well as so much of the game taking place in bright settings like outside and such, at first glance, it seems like one of those bright, positive games. While this game does have it's brighter, cheerful moments, underneath all that, at the core, I believe BioShock Infinite to be a darker game, when you consider certain parts of the storyline and such, especially when delving deep into the story. Overall, I've had loads of fun playing this game and think it to be a masterpiece of a game, if I do say so myself. I'd recommend this game to anyone without second thoughts!

reviewText:
Bioshock Infinite is a First Person Shooter set in the floating city of Columbia. In stark contrast to the previous game's Rapture city, Columbia is all about blind faith and unity instead of cynicism and individuality. We are sent to Columbia in order to capture a girl who goes by the name of Elizabeth and return her to New York in order to pay off your gambling debts. Upon entering the city we walk in to a rather jolly festival with games, prizes and free magical powers for some reason. Everything seems just dandy until a mysterious symbol appears on your hand, you are spotted then all hell breaks loose. At first you only have a pistol to defend yourself with though it is more than enough to deal with the early enemies as one headshot is all it takes to put them down. In a rather weird design decision you are given some of the game's most powerful powers at the start of the game effectively making you an unstoppable killing machine. Like its predecessors you will still have an energy bar to make sure you don't rely on it too heavily.

The only way to recharge your energy bar is by consuming salty foods or salty beverages. Why it runs off of salt or why you don't just carry a few packets in your pocket remains a complete mystery. Truth be told the powers themselves feel forced into Infinite since they have become a series staple even if it feels really out of place here. Ultimately these powers are a good thing as they lend much more variety to the combat which there will be a lot of. While the other two Bioshocks focused on subtle horror and enemies were meant to feel threatening Infinite goes the full action route and will have you facing hordes upon hordes of goons. It's a change of pace that really harms the experience as Bioshock has never been known for having good combat and very few of the enemies are memorable while fewer still are enjoyable to fight. Some of the special enemies we have is a bullet spongy teleporting bloke and a rocketeer that doesn't reload, can see through walls and will shoot a rocket into your face even if you are right in front of him whilst taking no damage.

One of the worst enemies is a giant cyborg who forces you to use Infinite's new skylines feature which allows you to hook onto a rail and either ride it or jump to higher grounds. It's a cool feature but will mostly be used for getting to higher ground as riding on one will make you into a human pi√±ata as the enemies are good shots. The problem with the giant is that he is simply too agile for the extremely slow movement speed of this game and for some strange reason our character can only leap an incredible amount off the ground only when you are looking at a crane to hang on to. We also suffer from fall damage unless we jump off a skyline as if adding more velocity to the landing makes it safer. Very petty things to critic a video game about no doubt but these odd contradictions are put in the spotlight when facing the giants and becoming aware of how awesome it would be if you could use your mysterious jumping skills to fight these raging beasts midair instead of waddling around like a new born lamb. In a game where you can shoot crows out of your wrists and has gone to the full action route it wouldn't be that out of place or it could be made into a power that uses your energy bar to keep it balanced.

We still have a health bar that can be refilled with random food or health kits but in addition we know also have a shield bar that recharges itself after not taking damage for some time. It sounds like that may make the game too easy though it is so weak that you can't play this like a cover based shooter. Searching your environments you can find tonics that will allow you to either upgrade your health, shield or energy bars. For some reason we now have a two weapon limit which is a subjectively bad change from its predecessors since you will likely be relying on the same two proven and upgraded guns while ignoring any new ones that may show up. That ends up making the combat even more boring due to not wanting to experiment with your load-out in case there is a vicious trap right around the corner. You can't carry much ammo but this is never really a problem as your sidekick Elizabeth gives you supplies whenever you need it most and she never seems to run out of stuff which confirms the theory that a woman's purse is a door to another dimension and is why they can fit a near infinite number of objects in there.

She won't actively help in fights but she can open small pockets to other dimensions in set places that allows her to spawn friendly turrets, supplies or a vantage point to climb up to. With her around you never have to worry about ammo since she will toss some your way whenever you are running low making sections when she is not around very noticeable. One of the things that really irks me is that there is no manual saving and you will have to wait until you reach one of the sparsely spaced auto-save points. As long as you don't leave the game or it doesn't crash there is no fear of losing any progress since Elizabeth will not allow you to die and will bring you back to life no matter what happens and how many times she does so.  It does remove any tension from Infinite and respawning was in the previous Bioshocks though you cannot disable it here. Elizabeth will be pretty much the only friendly face you'll be seeing and is a rather interesting character who is not afraid to immediately beat you with a book for breaking a hole in her ceiling. Our character is fully voiced as well and named Booker but while being important to the story he never has anything interesting to say.

Environments themselves are both beautiful and occasionally open ended allowing plenty of exploration. The surreal look of a city floating in the skies never gets old and the steam-punk theme of the game really suits it. Searching your surroundings will net you all kind of goodies like money, food or voxophones that will fill you in to the back-story of characters or environments. A very neat idea was with the cryptic codes written in blood that require you to find a book to decipher it with and then follow its clue to find a stash of treasure. This only happens twice in the game but it was a really neat feature that I would have loved to see more of. Money is a really important factor that will allow you to buy ammo and supplies as well as upgrading both your weapons and powers. One very powerful thing that you can't buy is ‚ÄúEquipment‚Äù that you can wear on four parts of your body for really nice bounces such as being able to reload 30% faster or creating a friendly ghosts when you kill an enemy with a trap. All of your powers can be placed around the environment like landmines to surprise your enemies leading to some potentially interesting fights if you are undetected and allowed the time to rig the battlefield beforehand.

The story of Infinite starts off interesting and starts losing steam from then on. Near the end of the game it really goes downhill as it has you fighting ghosts and finding rifts in a really long winded filler section. While Bioshock‚Äôs trademark melee weapon was a wrench, in Infinite it is a Riddick style spinning blade which also lets you latch onto the skylines. They are nowhere near as deadly as you'd imagine and are effectively a much cooler looking wrench though you can use it at the press of a button instead of having to equip it which can mean life or death when in close range. Some people say its the worst game in the bioshock triplet and they maybe right, because the first two were too damn good.

This game offers everything i loved in the other bioshock games: a unique setting, an interesting story, nice visuals (not as outstanding for its time like bioshock 1, but who cares? still good), surprisingly many ways to play the game and some really good voice actors (at least if you play the game in the original language).

Bioshock infinite offers some funny mechanics, with even more possibilities as in the first two games, simply because of yoour new friend: the hook.

After all, i would give 9/10 points for Bioshock Infinite, just to show there is allways the possibility to get better.

reviewText:
Bioshock Infinite is a First Person Shooter set in the floating city of Columbia. In stark contrast to the previous game's Rapture city, Columbia is all about blind faith and unity instead of cynicism and individuality. We are sent to Columbia in order to capture a girl who goes by the name of Elizabeth and return her to New York in order to pay off your gambling debts. Upon entering the city we walk in to a rather jolly festival with games, prizes and free magical powers for some reason. Everything seems just dandy until a mysterious symbol appears on your hand, you are spotted then all hell breaks loose. At first you only have a pistol to defend yourself with though it is more than enough to deal with the early enemies as one headshot is all it takes to put them down. In a rather weird design decision you are given some of the game's most powerful powers at the start of the game effectively making you an unstoppable killing machine. Like its predecessors you will still have an energy bar to make sure you don't rely on it too heavily.

The only way to recharge your energy bar is by consuming salty foods or salty beverages. Why it runs off of salt or why you don't just carry a few packets in your pocket remains a complete mystery. Truth be told the powers themselves feel forced into Infinite since they have become a series staple even if it feels really out of place here. Ultimately these powers are a good thing as they lend much more variety to the combat which there will be a lot of. While the other two Bioshocks focused on subtle horror and enemies were meant to feel threatening Infinite goes the full action route and will have you facing hordes upon hordes of goons. It's a change of pace that really harms the experience as Bioshock has never been known for having good combat and very few of the enemies are memorable while fewer still are enjoyable to fight. Some of the special enemies we have is a bullet spongy teleporting bloke and a rocketeer that doesn't reload, can see through walls and will shoot a rocket into your face even if you are right in front of him whilst taking no damage.

One of the worst enemies is a giant cyborg who forces you to use Infinite's new skylines feature which allows you to hook onto a rail and either ride it or jump to higher grounds. It's a cool feature but will mostly be used for getting to higher ground as riding on one will make you into a human pi√±ata as the enemies are good shots. The problem with the giant is that he is simply too agile for the extremely slow movement speed of this game and for some strange reason our character can only leap an incredible amount off the ground only when you are looking at a crane to hang on to. We also suffer from fall damage unless we jump off a skyline as if adding more velocity to the landing makes it safer. Very petty things to critic a video game about no doubt but these odd contradictions are put in the spotlight when facing the giants and becoming aware of how awesome it would be if you could use your mysterious jumping skills to fight these raging beasts midair instead of waddling around like a new born lamb. In a game where you can shoot crows out of your wrists and has gone to the full action route it wouldn't be that out of place or it could be made into a power that uses your energy bar to keep it balanced.

We still have a health bar that can be refilled with random food or health kits but in addition we know also have a shield bar that recharges itself after not taking damage for some time. It sounds like that may make the game too easy though it is so weak that you can't play this like a cover based shooter. Searching your environments you can find tonics that will allow you to either upgrade your health, shield or energy bars. For some reason we now have a two weapon limit which is a subjectively bad change from its predecessors since you will likely be relying on the same two proven and upgraded guns while ignoring any new ones that may show up. That ends up making the combat even more boring due to not wanting to experiment with your load-out in case there is a vicious trap right around the corner. You can't carry much ammo but this is never really a problem as your sidekick Elizabeth gives you supplies whenever you need it most and she never seems to run out of stuff which confirms the theory that a woman's purse is a door to another dimension and is why they can fit a near infinite number of objects in there.

She won't actively help in fights but she can open small pockets to other dimensions in set places that allows her to spawn friendly turrets, supplies or a vantage point to climb up to. With her around you never have to worry about ammo since she will toss some your way whenever you are running low making sections when she is not around very noticeable. One of the things that really irks me is that there is no manual saving and you will have to wait until you reach one of the sparsely spaced auto-save points. As long as you don't leave the game or it doesn't crash there is no fear of losing any progress since Elizabeth will not allow you to die and will bring you back to life no matter what happens and how many times she does so.  It does remove any tension from Infinite and respawning was in the previous Bioshocks though you cannot disable it here. Elizabeth will be pretty much the only friendly face you'll be seeing and is a rather interesting character who is not afraid to immediately beat you with a book for breaking a hole in her ceiling. Our character is fully voiced as well and named Booker but while being important to the story he never has anything interesting to say.

Environments themselves are both beautiful and occasionally open ended allowing plenty of exploration. The surreal look of a city floating in the skies never gets old and the steam-punk theme of the game really suits it. Searching your surroundings will net you all kind of goodies like money, food or voxophones that will fill you in to the back-story of characters or environments. A very neat idea was with the cryptic codes written in blood that require you to find a book to decipher it with and then follow its clue to find a stash of treasure. This only happens twice in the game but it was a really neat feature that I would have loved to see more of. Money is a really important factor that will allow you to buy ammo and supplies as well as upgrading both your weapons and powers. One very powerful thing that you can't buy is ‚ÄúEquipment‚Äù that you can wear on four parts of your body for really nice bounces such as being able to reload 30% faster or creating a friendly ghosts when you kill an enemy with a trap. All of your powers can be placed around the environment like landmines to surprise your enemies leading to some potentially interesting fights if you are undetected and allowed the time to rig the battlefield beforehand.

The story of Infinite starts off interesting and starts losing steam from then on. Near the end of the game it really goes downhill as it has you fighting ghosts and finding rifts in a really long winded filler section. While Bioshock‚Äôs trademark melee weapon was a wrench, in Infinite it is a Riddick style spinning blade which also lets you latch onto the skylines. They are nowhere near as deadly as you'd imagine and are effectively a much cooler looking wrench though you can use it at the press of a button instead of having to equip it which can mean life or death when in close range. It does have the best combat in the series but even so it is not particularly good, making it a real shame they went for the heavy action route. I would suggest not buying this game just because you really liked the last few games as Infinite is quite a departure from the desolate and creepy city of Rapture. With that in mind it is still a very decent game that is worth a look by those that like a combination of both FPS and RPG.

reviewText:
A lighthouse, a cryptic message, and an impossible city. The stage is set for another adventure through the grim, but surprisingly sunny, world of Bioshock.

The original Bioshock is a landmark in immersive videogame narrative and incredible design. It combined wonderfully designed aestethics with cool gameplay elements and a nice story to boot. For those who were truly interested there was plenty of room to explore and learn more of the fallen city of Rapture. Infinite then had a lot to live up to.

Infinite takes you to the flying city of Columbia, a seceded state from early America that left the blasphemous world below behind to ascend to a plane closer to god. You're former private eye with a checkered past who is hired to retrieve a girl from this flying utopia. How hard can it be?

Plenty hard. As it turns out, you're expected, and they're not happy. Inifite has you duke it out in the streets of Columbia while listening to the zealous chants of radical prophets and out of control rebels. The atmosphere is piled on at every turn and the game spares no expense to show you new and crazier things than you held possible. It is an exercise in world building of the highest order that adresses social, racial and religious themes to make you, the player, contemplate your actions and you make your way through the game.

However, for all the grandeur and splendor found in its presentation, the execution leaves something to be desired. Do not misunderstand, the story unfolds perfectly and you're still given room to explore. The problem is in the gameplay. Infinite borrows much of its combat from the original Bioshock, but trims away a lot of the fat and only leaves a bare bones set of options. Most battles revolve around bullet pumping and a bit of power flailing, while the combat systems in Bioshock 2 introduced so many cool things. This is Infinite's main problem. After a few hours, the sun doesn't shine so bright anymore while you stride into another gunfight.

Luckily, Infinite spares no expense to keep the pace up so you can make your way through the story at a proper pace. This makes it a game to be enjoyed for its content, while it skimps a bit on the gameplay. That said, if you fancy yourself a masochist, feel free to dive into the 1999 mode. A super hard mode that leaves you reeling if you don't prepare. That'll keep you occupied for a while. Still, Bioshock Infinite is an experience you will need to try at least once.

reviewText:
Okay, let me preface this by acknowledging that this game is reasonably well polished, visually impressive and doesn't really contain any content that is particularly offensive.

But otherwise this game is incredibly bad, and I am going to lay out why.

I think the first thing to do is to comment on the gameplay in comparison with it's forebears, Bioshock and Bioshock 2. This game does not play much like them, yet it plays too much like them. The gameplay was stripped down, with numerous features removed and replaced, and yet no significant work was done to improve the combat. This is a problem because Bioshock combat isn't good, it needs elements to it to give it flavour and strategy, such as hacking, interacting with elements in the environment and making enemies target one another, etc. Infinite only has possession as a function for replacing hacking and mind control but it does this with no flair at all. Hacked turrents/enemies are invincible when they are your ally meaning when the ability runs out you have to deal with them then. The Vigors have almost no narrative reason to be in the game and they lack variety even moreso than the Plasmids from prior games.

The weapons are a massive disappointment. Only allowing for two weapons carried massively cuts down on variety of gameplay yet again, their upgrades are not interesting and just change some stats. And you're penalised for not focusing on upgrading only a couple of weapons that you will use all the time. The gunplay is terrible, enemies are bullet sponges making the combat slow and monotonous. I also think that though some areas of the game are very pretty, much of the game takes place in pretty nondescript corridors, or generic open areas.

Enemies simply spawn in waves or wander around randomly. They never use tactics, there's only a handful of enemy types. The most interesting part of the game is a fairly standard stealth section and the one boss" fight it has was a massive slog. At no point is this game every truly fun to play for all the obscene amount of money that clearly went into it.

Having said that

reviewText:
It's undeniable that the first Bioshock has advanced the narrative in this medium quite a bit, and Infinite is just another step in the right direction. Of course you get the amazing narrative you'd expect; Elizabeth is one of the best companions in gaming. The developers took their time in developing her character and build the relationship between her & Booker. A character of this quality has not been done since Half Life 2, and even then the comparison falls in Infinite's favor.

The level design is another standout. The addition of the skyline was ingenious as it allowed the developers to open up the map in a way where it complimented the setting of a city in space.

Superpowers, now called vigors instead of plasmids, allows the player to mix a match their play style. There's a decent selection of vigors that allows the player to experiment with certain combos and leads to some replay value. Some of the returning powers from the old game have been streamlined to allow for easier management. For example, instead of having to switch between enemy specific plasmids, the power of possession now encompasses all enemies. This aids the somewhat clumsy interface that plagued the first game.

There is simply no other game like Infinite at the moment. It is frankly one of the most memorable games I've ever had the luxury of playing. Thanks to the superb narrative and game design, Infinite will sit in my mind for days to come.

reviewText:
The short: Starts out kinda slow, but it's a great alternate world of the Guilded Age that's achingly beautiful to play in. The shooting mechanic is fun but generic, as is the spellcasting/Vigors powers which is a little dissappointing. This is all secondary towards the story telling which is excellently voiced and written, though pacing in the beginning needs work. There are plot holes (the ending, the mother story thread, etc) and jarring game mechanics (Elizabeth's powers) but nothing preventing you from wanting  to see how this all unveils. For all my quibbles, it's smoothed out with the charming characters and world that Infinite presents.

The Long:
After 2 hours in to Infinite, I stopped playing this game.
I felt bored, and as pretty as the world was presented in this wonderous alternate steam-punk reality of a cotton candied 1910-esque US, it just wasn't enought to keep me interested because I've seen this theme many times in lower detail and quality, and after 10 minutes wondering around, it all felt familiar. The clever plot points were slipped in from early on, but a bit too obvious and/or heavy handedly but at least a good attempt was made.  The gun play is typical, movement was typical, vigors/spells were unique enough but nothing unheard of. And that's when I stopped. The story was being too subtle, especially for a player like me, who wants to see all places presented, thus making the story even slower.

After some nudging from friends, I booted it back on and trudged forward. Once you meet Elizabeth, everything this world and story was building upon started to click. Factions, trials, wonders, backstory, expositories, trageties, horrors, betrayals and tender moments all come at you like a torrential storm surge, each trying to overwhelm the other in waves. Weirdly, through this maelstrom of motivations and hatched plots, the characters and why the world is the way it is, was and/or to be all make some semblance of sense, albeit broken sense if you're not caught up in the spectical/revelation and think about it a bit. The voice acting and dialog is wonderful and believable, there is chemistry between Booker and Elisabeth in their voicing and 3D depictions. You get the sense of balance between tragedy and resilience from Elisabeth, while Booker is definately a man with a past and skin he's not comfortable in anymore.

The ending... I'll let you be the judge due to the nature of it. It's definitely you take what you will with it since there really isn't a proper answer besides speculation to be honest. The one the game presents is possible but flawed in my mind, but given the game's title, who am I to really judge? Play it and see if you choose to believe it as it is one of the infinite possibilities.

reviewText:
After playing this game numerous times (once on Normal, once on 1999) I can safely say it's one of the best stories of all time. The game, however, sucks.

Lemmie explain.
In the original Bioshock, you had 7 weapons (8 if you include the Camera) that you can carry on you at any given time. This, coupled with the 3 types of ammo for nearly every weapon, allowed you to approach situations and adjust to them as they came. In addition to the interesting weapons, their upgrades were even more fascinating. The ability to freeze somebody by smacking them over the head, then shoot them with fire bullets? Why not?! The possibilites for an interesting combat experience were endless.

Bosses in the original also had depth, and were interesting characters. You knew them, you saw what they'd done, you'd heard their words, and agreed with why they must die for you to continue onwards. They also had a habbit for knowing when it was high time to fall over, meaning, after their primary mechanic was exploited, their minutes quickly became numbered, creating a fast paced, difficult, non mundane boss fighting experience. It wasn't just the bosses that died without a ridiculous amount of bullets being pumped into their face, regular enemies didn't take half a nuclear arsenal to bring down, and with good reason; they were just drug heads in t-shirts with the occasional power. Nothing more.

My apologies for ranting, but there's a point to this. The reason I mentioned the previous two things in those long drawn out excuses for paragraphs it to show what Infinite is lacking. You can hold a maximum of two weapons (the melee weapon now passively always being attached) and thus decreasing the possible methods of dealing with an issue by an exponentional amount. The upgrades for weapons in Infinite are also a joke, being the standard Reduced Recoil
recommended: Increase Ammo Capacity". That is boring. This is why I mark off the weapon system as terrible.\n\nThe second thing to complain about in this game is the combat sections (if they can even be called that). Interesting locations and cool locales taken thrown headfirst into a game of "Who can be the biggest bullet sponge." The enemies act with a reckless disregard for their own safety and recieve no penalty for it because they can take more hits than an IS-2 tank. It's not interesting fighting enemies who can run up to you and tank all the damage and just punch you in the face. The mess of a combat system quickly becomes a chore when you realize who Ken Levine called in when the bosses all called in sick: Handymen

reviewText:
Recent convo with a dear friend with questionable taste made me want to go a bit more in depth on why I have a problem with this game. Forgive my ranting, derivitive wording, and sloppy editing. Ill probably do something about that at some point in the future.

Allosaurus Rex, a youtuber I quite respect, described interactive media as running on parallel lines of narrative devices and player interaction; A games predetermined narrative, the players input into the interactive gamespace, and how those two lines influence each other. If the parallel runs properly, then player input should serve as a narrative device on its own, even in a mechanically linear game. Take for example Hotline Miami, its usage of neon psychedelia and bass thumping combat queues to reinforce the players disconnect from the games violence, and binding it to the player characters own disconnect. The game uses its interactivity to reinforce the narrative and connect the player and character headspaces; The gameplay means the same to the player what the actions its portraying mean to the character. The narrative flows and the gameplay flows with it.

The core thematic and narrative concept of Bioshock Infinite, as is traditional of the franchise, is the father-child relationship of the protaganist's filtered through a lens of idealistic extremism, with Randian Objectivism replaced as the focus of satire with colonial American Nationalism. The Father-Child of the story being the player character Booker and his ward Elizabeth. The scripted narrative wants us to feel connected to and ultimately protective of this ward, as the authorities want her back under their control. Protect Elizabeth, that‚Äôs the narrative line. The game itself is a linear shooter. Once combat, the gameplay proper, kicks in Elizabeth recedes to the background, immune to damage and only interacting with the player to interrupt the flow of combat to spoon-feed them health and ammo, completely ignored by enemies. That‚Äôs the player line. The parallel is obviously not well maintained. A narrative focusing entirely on a cast of two characters and their interactions and how Booker, the vehicle for the player to experience and connect to this story, grows connected to Elizabeth cannot subsist on script alone, something mechanical, something involving the player, needs to be established for that relationship to mean anything. A character as critical to the scripted narrative as Elizabeth cannot be a non-entity in gameplay. Even the excessivity of the violence becomes jarring in the games narrative context. In the original Bioshock the body count made sense within the games world; Jack was engineered to take and dole out damage, and the mentally unstable enemies made suspension of disbelief for their behavior easy, but in Infinite there‚Äôs no real logical reason that arguably rational people would be so happy to zerg rush a killing machine like Booker. Going even more basic than that, its a failure. One of the first (ultimately pointless) moral choices the player is confronted with is a pseudo-lynching of an inter-racial couple that the player is forced to participate in. You are given a ball and told to throw it at the couple. At its most basic level, a shooter requires two forms of input: aim and shoot projectiles. So when given a projectile and a target to aim at, of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing course you make the choice with button prompts. Instead of letting the player choose this on their own, potentially letting the setting influence the choice as the pressure of the moment is on them, its reduced to binary hand holding. Without a mechanical factor to bridge the gap between player gameplay and character action, you stop being able to connect to the story as a factor in it and just become a spectator to it. You‚Äôre just shooting ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and that is a criminal waste of potential in an interactive medium.

Its a sloppiness that persists even to the scripted narrative alone. Its heavily praised usage of themes like racial inequality and nationalism are barely present. Compared to real-world racism in real-world America at the time, what goes down in Columbia is tame. Barely any mention of abuse, either physical or verbal, of the black and irish underclass is present in the dialogue. And by the half-way point these ostensibly critical aspects of the game world are thrown out the window for a nonsensical many-worlds plotline that ultimately devolves into the most basic of grandfather paradoxes that uses quantum mechanics as a synonym for magic.

Instead of solving the core issues with the concepts presented, like escort missions or enemy AI, the developers over-simplified or cut it out to the detriment of the narrative as a whole. This is a pretty consistent issue; The vigors are a glaring leftover from the Rapture setting. They make no sense in the context of Columbia and its culture, and even in gameplay terms they quickly become redundant to the player, as half of your vigors overlap in use. Even the shooting mechanics end up inconsistent and frustrating. A game with a two weapon limit has no business having a weapon upgrade system. Ammo will never be consistent enough for the player to keep their favored weapons, and the curve of weapon introduction insures that at several critical moments of the game the player is left with un-upgraded weaponry as their only valid option. It limits your arsenal, disrupts its own upgrade system, and leaves the player to deal with its schizophrenic ammo drop system where enemies most of the time drop ammo for weapons that you don‚Äôt have and can‚Äôt get.

TL;DR This game is a pretentious, badly designed mess. For all its praised as being this fresh innovative piece or art, its just another sloppy shooter with a bad story in an industry over-poluted with sloppy shooters with bad stories.

reviewText:
Bioshock Infinite has always been an interesting series in the history of video games. The developers of the game wen't all out with this one and it turned out just fine. The game visually looks like a painting and it's a beautiful site to behold. Often I stop and take in all that I am looking at. The people in the background doing their own thing, Barbershop quartet. But I feel that all of this really overshadows the rest of the game. Is Bioshock Infinite overrated? Yes, but I still think it's worthy of a playthrough. I feel that too many people praized this game eventhough it's not that amazing as people say it is. If you like a story with a FPS Style themed game, than you would enjoy this for sure.

So, here's the story. The story is about the protagonist of the game, Booker dewitt who has find a girl named Elizabeth and bring to her back to a certain person in New York. Once he finds Elizabeth, you'll be surprised at how good and realistic they made her. Almost all the time through the game, her character was very spontanious. The voice acting in the game is very satisfying. The combat in the game is also pretty satisfying as well. I played with the sniper rifle pretty much the whole time in my playthrough because I found it awesome to see the enemies head blow off when shoot. I found this game also to be a handy tool to improve your aim in games. And with the new addition of vigors, you'll have more variation in your kills. Something that was a little disappointing in the game was the half non and half linear level design and I love games where you can explore everything in the level but this game sort of lacks that. I also don't like that you walk in an empty room, go into the next door, all enemies and you kill them, walk into another empty area and walk upstairs and more enemies and kill them all and then another empty area. If you know what I am talking about, you'll understand what I mean.

But this is the thing that I truly dislike the most about the game. It's too damn easy! Yes, when you are in combat, Elizabeth often throws you ammo, salts, and health whenever something is low and I actually don't like the idea of that. I also don't like when you press a key on the keyboard and there's an arrow that points you in the right direction. I'd rather ignore all of these things and enjoy the game without it being this easy. I'd like a challenge with these types of games. There are different types of big daddy's in this game now and they are like elderly people put into this body to prolong their life. Without spoilers I would like to say my opinions of the ending. Let me just say, ending are not always that easy when people make a game and this ending is a little illogical at first, but on further notice you begin to think more about it and you kind of reflect about everything that happened in the game. Apart from that I would give it a 7/10. You should better play the original Bioshock because that is a true classic. This game got too much praize for what it was actually not, but I'd still reccommend it.

reviewText: I really enjoyed the first 2 Bioshock games and I was looking for this one to see if Bioshock game can still offer really good gameplay, and a great strory with a great setting. I will start with the good I would say that the game does look really good, does have some nice areas to explore and it does have an interesting story. However, I realised that the story can become a little bit predictible towards the end as the second half of the game really drags on for quite some time, but it does have a really strong beggining and ending. The story is also riddled with plot holes that really don't make sense once you start thinkinh about it. Then theres the gameplay which the weakest. As for a Bioshock game, the shooting is lackluster and as a FPS it is also lackluster. I have just happened to play better FPS games like Crysis 2 and 3 or FarCry 3, whereas Infinte tries way too hard to be a FPS. The vigors are also pretty useless as you will only find yourself using one or two whereas the rest are not that interesting or fun to use, and the same can be said for the weapons. And finally, the vigor and weapon upgrades are also useless as they don't make your guns or vigors that powerful, no matter how many times you upgrade them. Overall I honestly wouldn't recomend buying Bioshock Infinte but instead go for Bioshock 1 and 2 as they are much better games.

reviewText: The game had a nice intro, and cool concept. However, as you play, you will start to notice how shallow the game is. Environments dont respond to you, NPCs dont respond to you, and you feel like the game has no soul. The flying city did not feel like a flying city. You spend most of the time in rooms and hallways. At many points in turns into a call of duty duck and cover til you win strategy type of game. The combat gets boring, the vigors get boring, the 'boss battle' is freaking rediculous - but with a great ending - I still felt somewhat satisfied and happy to have played it. If this game were a movie, Id suggest waiting to catch it on TV.

reviewText: BioShock Infinite is a really fun game with a very unique story. If you haven't played this game yet but intend to, do yourself a favor and DO NOT spoil the twist ending for youself. Like any game, it has its imperfections: I feel like the new Health/Salts system is nowhere as good as the system in the first BioShock Health/Eve system. Here, instead of having several health kits and even hypos on you that allow you to refresh your health and eve in a battle, you need to actively look for those items in your environment which can often be a hassle because the salts are so scarce. While under different circumstances this system might have worked, in BioShock Infinite it just becomes annoying after a while. Another qualm that I have is the Vigors themselves. While each of the vigors is unique and can be combo'd with another vigor, most of the vigors do essentially the same thing: they disable enemies in an area for a few seconds and deal some damage. There are some exceptions but ultimately out of the entire arsenal of vigors you end up just going around using one of them to do all the work. Unlike BioShock 1 and 2, the storyline is now much more linear and while some sandbox elements were added such as a couple of secret locations, they're barely noticeable. The Haevy Hitters, which are the equivalents of the Big Daddies from previous games have been reduced from enemies that you need to carefully plan your fights with to simple bullet sponges.\nUltimately, despite these flaws the game is still very fun and enjoyable, has a great story and I do recommend, but it doesn't live up to the original BioShock.\n

reviewText:
This isn't a video game, this is a piece of artwork (on par with other moving paintings like Shadow of the Colossus) that you have the privilege of experiencing.  The story and characters will transport you to another place entirely, a city in the clouds where the idea of white, American, Christian, capitalist culture has been turned into what can only be described as a haunting cult.

Don't go into this game expecting to find the greatest shooting mechanics ever created; that isn't what it's about (which isn't to say the shooting and fighting isn't fantastic).  It's about the immersion from the brilliantly crafted storyline and beautiful writing.  This is one of those rare games where you truly sympathize and connect with the characters, especially Elizabeth - they feel alive, largely in due to the amazing voice acting.  Honestly,  if this had been written as a novel as opposed to a video game, it would be a modern classic.

I never thought any video game could come close to making me re-live the emotion I first felt when playing Ocarina of Time (my favorite title ever) but this comes extremely close.  If Ocarina is a 10, this is a 9.99999999999999999~.

Play the game.
Wipe away the debt.

reviewText:
After playing this game I'm wondering if there is a universe in which I didn't like it. The answer is probably NOT, because this is one of the most ridiculously beautiful game I've ever played.
Does it have amazing graphics? Yes, it does.
Does it have amazing voice acting? Yes, it does.
Does it have the most realistic, fun and talented female companion of all time? Yes, it does.
Does it have great variety of combat scenarios? Yes, it does.
Does it have a complex, incredibly beautiful, engaging, feelingful storyline? The tears of sadness and joy in my face says so.
Does it have a satisfying ending? F*CK YEAH IT DOES!

Sadly, I don't have enough knowledge of the English language to come up with any more adjectives to rate this game. This isn't even a game, it's a work of art. Those who say that games can't have the same impact as movies or books ARE F. STUPID. And those who say this game in particular does not have at least one of the best storylines ever didn't understand it. I guarantee it! Read a guide online and be amazed.

I rate it 10/10 for the story. I'll add another 3 for combat mechanics, 2 for graphics and scenery, and 2 more for the game longevity. So, 17/10.
Oh wait, did I mention Elizabeth? The companion? She's great, oh so great, that I think I'll add OVER 9000 points because of her. Yes, that sounds fine.

So yeah... my final rating for this game is an astounding OVER 9000/10. SHUT UP, the king can do as he likes!
I also loved the Rapture reference from Bioshock 1. One more point for that.
Play this game. PLAY IT.

Did I mention how great this story is?
