reviewText:
This is probably the best game in the world. That's not to say everyone will love it. I think almost everyone can gain something from playing this game. It is first and foremost an excellent shooter game. I'm no legend in FPS games, in fact I pretty much suck. I played it at default difficulty and the game provided a consistent challenge, but never felt impossible. The learning curve might be a tiny bit steep for players new to Bioshock or FPSs. However the game does an excellent job of introducing you to these gameplay elements, without drawing you out of the environment. And oh, what an environment it is.

The game is about a year and 6 months old now, and the version I played during Turkey Weekend 2014 was remarkably stable. There were maybe two or three minor visual bugs, and one instance where I had to reload a checkpoint to continue. That's literally it for errors, everything else was flawlessly executed. Graphically, a quad-core processor and budget video card will let you set the quality to max visuals. I recommend this, because it's an important part of playing the game. Really, do play this game on PC, at max settings. You do yourself a disservice otherwise.

To say it is art is to damn it with faint praise.

Bioshock Infinite is beautiful. It's like a painting in motion; a world of wonder brought to life in vivid color and ethereal light. The city of Columbia is brimming with breathtaking imagery, particularly during the first half of the game. Shafts of soft light fall on pools of water that ripple in realistic fashion; water that casts reflections on nearby surfaces. Anyone who has been to an indoor pool knows this visual phenomena. There are moments where I had to stop and just admire how gorgeous everything was. In that respect it's unlike any game I've ever played.

These sumtuous visuals are complemented with excellent sound engineering and a terrific music score. The careful listener will much enjoy some clever musical arrangements. Everything is voice-acted, and that too has been done with care. The voice actors for the protagonist, Booker DeWitt, and his companion Elizabeth, are excellent. Troy Baker, Booker's voice actor, did a particularly fine job of fitting his voice to the era. There is frequent dialogue between Booker and Elizabeth; these conversations provide a level of intimacy that is all too frequently absent from games with a narrative.

In short I can't recommend this game enough. It's like a book you can immerse yourself in. Provides a solid 15-20 hours of play. It's actually worth $50, but if you can get it on sale, do. This review can't do it justice. You have to experience it.

reviewText:
I honestly never played the original Bioshock. At the time of its release, I was a bit of a coward and its guise of a horror game pushed me away. When Bioshock Infinite was released, I didn't make the same mistake, and purchased it immediately.

I was not left dissappointed. The gameplay is like many singleplayer FPSs. It's simple and intuitive, with enemies often dying when you shoot them and a number of other means of murder being thrown into the mix.

Elizabeth, as your sole companion, is probably the greatest side kick you will ever have in a shooter. She doesn't get in the way, doesn't steal your kills, gives you stuff that you need, and obeys your orders without a second thought.

What really makes Infinite shine is its story. It's engaging, confusing, thought-provoking and probably enough to make it best game of the year.

Edit (2nd play through): Booker is so consumed with guilt that he developed a condition called Buttonphobia. This is clearly demonstrated in the game as he has the uncontrollable urge to slam his fist into every elevator button, in an attempt to smash it out of its metallic existence. I decided to replay the main game after getting the Season Pass on a sale, and also to complete some easy steam achievements that I've missed.

I honestly never played the original Bioshock. At the time of its release, I was a bit of a coward and its guise of a horror game pushed me away. When Bioshock Infinite was released, I didn't make the same mistake, and purchased it immediately.

I was not left dissappointed. The gameplay is like many singleplayer FPSs. It's simple and intuitive, with enemies often dying when you shoot them and a number of other means of murder being thrown into the mix.

Elizabeth, as your sole companion, is probably the greatest side kick you will ever have in a shooter. She doesn't get in the way, doesn't steal your kills, gives you stuff that you need, and obeys your orders without a second thought.

What really makes Infinite shine is its story. It's engaging, confusing, thought-provoking and probably enough to make it best game of the year.

reviewText:
First, I'll start off and say you don't have to play BioShock 1 and 2 to understand Infinite, as it has it's own story. It might be slightly confusing as to what's going on a few hours in, but it'll kick in. You have to pay attention foremost. Irrational Games went a different route in scenery this time. Although the creepy, dark atmosphere and enemies of Rapture is what made BioShock 1 & 2 so great, you're now in the clouds. And it looks beautiful. Add the soundtrack and it's double that.

Gameplay is similar to what you're used to in most types of shooters. You have a array of spells called vigors and you can cast them in combination to get a desired effect. There's weapons too and while you do need to shoot your way out of situations, they're not as exciting as using vigors.

Elizabeth is extremely smart and proves to be a very helpful self-dependant ally. So no, don't worry about being a Leon.

Infinite is a GOTY contender for many reasons. Top voice acting, a story that is better than anything Hollywood can ever come up with and fluid gameplay. If you want to play one of the best single players this year, get Infinite.

Despite having a difficult time actually running this gorgeous, intricate piece of artwork, I did have quite the good time by simply looking around. Cons
Simple gameplay (The game is still worth getting and is still challenging; trust me)
Nearly unavoidable choppy character animations

reviewText:
Bioshock Infinite is the third in the Bioshock series and takes place in a different environment. Both Bioshock 1 & 2 took place in the underwater city of Rapture, while Infinite takes place in the flying city of Columbia. In general though, the gameplay between the three games is very similar and if you liked parts 1 & 2, you should like Infinite as well.

A recap in case you haven‚Äôt played any of the Bioshock games yet:
Bioshock 1 showed what might happen in a world ruled by extreme practicality, everyone looking out for their own best interest. A man named Andrew Ryan created the equivalent of Atlas Shrugged‚Äôs ‚ÄúAtlantis.‚Äù In the underwater city of Rapture, there was economics without government oversight, art without censorship, and science without ethics. Imagine what the Olympics would be like if all athletes were allowed to take steroids or be otherwise enhanced. Rapture collapsed (figuratively) when people started ‚Äúsplicing‚Äù freely.  A substance called Adam was discovered from deep sea slugs that could be used to transfer modified genetic material to people. Everyone could buy these ‚Äúplasmids‚Äù giving themselves superhuman powers and other genetic modifications. Unfortunately people became addicted to this ‚Äúself-improvement‚Äù and a kind of civil war broke out which ended up leaving the city a ghost town. You show up in the final days of the city and try to find your way back to the surface.

In Bioshock 2, you learn more about the final days of Rapture, as well as what happened after the fall. A psychiatrist Sofia Lamb came to Rapture to try to solve the city‚Äôs problems, but she ended up creating an even bigger divide amongst the citizens. Dr. Lamb saw the potential to create a true Utopia (perfect world) but realized that to have a Utopian city requires Utopian citizens (everyone living to serve the greater good).  She tried to create the first Utopian using Adam gene splicing, with the result being a superhuman with all the memories and super powers of everyone in the city (bad idea). You play a different character from the first game trying to rescue someone held captive in the city a couple years after the events of Bioshock 1.

The story of Bioshock Infinite actually takes place before parts 1 or 2. In the flying city of Columbia, the opposite of Rapture has happened. The city is ruled by religion and actually seems like a great place (if you‚Äôre not a racial minority). Bear in mind that this takes place in the early 1900‚Äôs so there‚Äôs a lot of racism and discrimination. The first half hour of the game you might be shocked at how awesome Columbia is, with no crime, and everything is on the honor system. People don‚Äôt need to watch their stores because nobody steals. Instead of worshipping God, the people of Columbia seem to worship the Founding Fathers of the United States (George Washington, Ben Franklin, etc.). The city is controlled by ‚Äúthe Prophet‚Äù with the people gladly giving their lives for him if needed. As you go along you find that under the surface, the city is on the verge of revolution.

You play the character Booker DeWitt, a private detective looking for a girl being held prisoner somewhere in Columbia. When you find the girl Elizabeth, you realize that she has the power to create dimensional rifts and is revered (and feared) by the people of Columbia as a kind of messiah who will bring destruction to the sinful world below. The story is pretty complicated since it involves dimensional travel (maybe time travel?) and a lot of shifting loyalties. I‚Äôm still not 100% sure of what happened in the end but it‚Äôs a gripping ride nevertheless.

Bioshock Infinite is a First Person Shooter similar to Half-Life 2 in that it has no out of body ‚Äúcut scenes.‚Äù You see everything from the view of Booker DeWitt with the story happening around you. There isn‚Äôt too much variety in weapons, although a few of the weapons have different ‚Äúversions‚Äù since they‚Äôre used by different factions in the story. The game has ‚Äúvigors‚Äù which are basically the same as plasmids in the first 2 Bioshock games. Think of them as magic powers that you find along the way. You have a health bar and a ‚Äúsalts‚Äù bar (mana) and you find a lot of health and salt pickups, many of which are dropped by enemies when they die. The game also seems easier than Bioshock 1 & 2 because Elizabeth is with you most of the time as your ammo / health supplier. You don‚Äôt need to escort her and she tosses you items occasionally when you‚Äôre almost overwhelmed.

Pros:
+Excellent story that you ‚Äúlive‚Äù instead of read about. In Bioshock 1 & 2, you mostly learn the story by listening to recordings.
+Decently long game with a lot of replay value. I‚Äôve played through the game 3 times and I‚Äôm keeping it on my hard drive to play again.
+There‚Äôs a lot of variety in environment. You‚Äôre not stuck in an underwater city this time. You can fight in the sunny outdoors, flying along skylines, or in a ‚Äúhaunted house.‚Äù
+The price is pretty low for this game. It was so critically acclaimed that it‚Äôs constantly a sale headliner.

Cons:
-No multiplayer, but frankly I don‚Äôt see how multiplayer would add much. Maybe a co-op mode would be nice but is unnecessary.

Overall, Bioshock Infinite is definitely recommended to fans of shooter games and good stories. So many people seem to have the game that you could probably use Steam‚Äôs family sharing to play it off of your friends‚Äô accounts. It‚Äôs a pretty big download but definitely worth it.

A must-play!

Obviously no game is without flaws.Infinite felt a bit rushed in terms of the story especially at the end.Some elements of the plot and characters seem to be just thrown in the later bits.A certain character turns against you much too soon which made it an anti-climax.The writers/devs are much better than that.

Other stuff:

Being a Christian myself,I was happy to see a piece of media brave enough to question the tendency of humans to follow certain religions blindly without questioning the chaos they cause.The primary antagonist is the perfect portrayal of what a person is capable of doing in the name of religion.I just hope people don't forget that there are actual sensible Christians around but I digress.Kudos for questioning the authority of those with the most selfish of ambitions currently in power.

reviewText:
[Comrade's 2013 Experience of the Year]

After playing the game through its entirety, I was left in awe.

Both this game's setting and story are simply amazing, however the only actual negative was some of the gameplay itself. The environments were great, of course, but the actual weapons felt... weak and enemies became too bullet-spongy later on in the game. Elizabeth is a pretty interesting addition, as she runs around looking for stuff you're running low on in the middle of combat which saved my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• plenty of times. Though interesting she's almost the only actual face-to-face interaction you get beyond a few non-combat areas. And the vigors were... well they were alright but mostly ripped from the previous Bioshock.

It was the gun-play which was really disappointing. Things like only being able to carry two weapons pretty much forces you to carry a gun and a heavy weapon. Plus weapons have very little kick and the bulletspongy enemies make it feel like you're using a toy gun. At the end of the game ammo is very scarce and there are no vendors you can get ammo from at all. And really, it just felt terrible at points, I found myself wanting to just get combat over with just to get back to the amazing story.

I'd say its definitely worth a buy, as this is easily among the best stories ever told in a game. However in itself, not a good game. So I'd advise you play it on easy to get to the story bits faster.

Story: 10/10 (amazing)
Enviroment/World: 9/10 (awe-inspiring)
Combat: 3/10 (far too generic and far too much of it shoved in for a story-centric game)

reviewText: I've had some time to think about this game, and here are my overall thoughts. (SPOILER-FREE)\n\nBioshock Infinite is at its core an average single-player shooter game. However, this is not what compelled me to pick it up. I picked this game up for around 10 bucks during the Steam Black Friday sale, hearing that the story was excellent, and far better than what you'd see in an everyday shooter. After about a month of letting it sit in my library, I gave it a try. Damn, were my friends right. The story is what MADE the game. The world of Colombia is sprawling and full of life, which is surprising due to the subject matter. The character of Elizabeth gave the game heart and a way to convey its story through someone else's eyes, rather than the focused and violent sight of Mr. Booker Dewitt. The ending left me speechless, and I talked to my friends about it for hours. I tried the other Bioshocks, but they were not even close to the fun I had with Infinite. They were far too dark and overall lacked the polish of Infinite. Infinite's choice of a lighter atmosphere and a gripping story reeled me in and gave me an overall great experience. It was worth every penny.

reviewText:
After the great Bioshock (one of my most favourite games of all times) and a quite mediocre Bioshock 2 I was curious if Bioshock Infinite would be so amazing as the previews mentioned. Now I am glad I just bought it on Steam Autumn Sale for less than 10 ‚Ç¨...

Bioshock 3 is a shooter, quite different from the previous titles. By the setting in a town, floating in the sky, it lost all of it's dark and terrifying atmosphere which made Bioshock once so great.

So let's start by the good things:
Bioshock 3 isn't bad at all.

Technical:
Graphically fitting you walk through a shiny world, see scyscrapers and go by the sky-line railsystem from platform to the other. I played the game with highest graphics, but it is only mediocre. Sound is ok, but not overwhelming.

Fighting:
Weapons are varying and for every taste you get some weapons. In my case the huntsman carbine and the pig flak volley gun... *cough*
Enemies act not too stupid. Only few enemy types.
The vigors, Jedi-like forces that support in quite funny ways, are quite different and function quite good.

Story:
The story seems easy at the start, but gets very twisted later. You might need more than playthrough to get everything of the story. Some few hidden places you can find while playing, giving you special equipment like hats and stuff.

I am totally disappointed. Forget the trailers...

reviewText:
I just finished the last DLC of this game (Burial at Sea Episode 2), and I'm just blown away by this amazing work of art.

This game is simply amazing.

There will be spoilers ahead for anyone who hasn't played this yet.

Story
----------------------------------

Bioshock Infinite's story is possibly one of the most complex stories that I've ever encountered in a game. The whole concept of infinite universes and 'constants and variables' is an ever present theme throughout the series.

After completing the base game, I was left with a few questions, but the two follow-up DLCs: Burial at Sea 1 & 2, gave me such an emotional and satisfying ending that I was left with no ill-feelings. I'll just say straight up that if you love a good story, which is so massive and complex, yet understandable, this game is perfect for you.


Gameplay
----------------------------------
Bioshock Infinite has some very enjoyable gameplay. Combining FPS, with rapid skylines, and vigors (special abilities), makes this game mind blowingly awesome. Every shot, every power, feels impactful. The visual detail is stunning for a game which has an almost 'cartoony' feel to it. Riding skylines, and hopping from location to location feels amazing and action-filled as you quickly hop off to take down an enemy, only to run back and swing along looking for your next target.

For the more tactical players, setting off vigor traps, or possessing enemy structures can turn the tide of battle in an instant.

The weapons....oh man the weapons. The time period of this game brings back all the 'old-school' weapons which have a certain kind of feel to them which can't be explained. The detail of the gun models, the sounds, the firing rate, and the damage it inflicts just gives a satisfying feeling at the end of a battle. There are all kinds of weapons for any kind of player. Snipers, pistols, shotguns, grenade launchers, and a ton more.

Gameplay wise, this game deserves a playthrough at the very least...but no, there's more...

Characters
----------------------------------
Oh my god, where do I begin?? First off, Elizabeth is possibly the most lovable, attractive, helpful character I've ever seen in a game, period.

The voice actors for both Booker, and Elizabeth are simply amazing. They made the characters feel so real, so personal, and the story could not have gone anywhere without top quality voice actors.



There's literally paragraphs upon paragraphs I could write about this masterpiece of a game, but no, buy this game and it's DLCs. Play it. Enjoy it.

9.9/10  I wanted Elizabeth to live :'(

This game is a contendor for Game of The Year only for its story, the gameplay is subpar. reviewText:
By far, this is one of the most amazing games I've ever played.  It's story, Its caracters, Its gameplay, Its music and the list goes on...

It was a completely different game from the original Bioshock and even the DLC, (that I did a review for too) despite being set in the same location as the original Bioshock and being a direct prequel, still is as different as a cat is from a dog. Let's start with the story. The story was a tad longer than the original Bioshock. It does not have different endings like it, but leads to one concluding (un)expected climax. All of the endings (by all I mean the ones from the dlc too) made me sad. It doesn't reach the tears level sad, that it could aswell have, if they had put a little more work into it, but is still pretty sad. Maybe, because I personally didn't understand the characters completely, or maybe just because I am a heartless ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• who would punch another person for a laugh. One of the game's main mind-tricks are constants and variables. It's always mentioned in the story. They seem to be very important, but in truth, the little parts and the decisions you make don't really matter. The only difference the pendant you chose made, was which one was on Elizabeth's neck throughout the rest of the game. It makes you think that the variables matter, but in truth, the only things that matter and make the story are the constants, which leads me to the characters. The characters, as I said are very well voiced and animated. You can actually feel their inner suffering and wish to help as much as you can, but the game is, technically a sad corridor walk.  If I were any of those characters, I would have taken the other paths so many times, but the game just doesn't allow you to do it, despite being an RPG, with a little bit of open world, (as tiny optional areas to explore). Though, to anyone playing this game, I will again and again recommend exploring the hidden rooms, listening to the voxophones and doing optional objectives, as you will get more money, infusions, and even access some vigors earlier than you are supposed to. Also, it is good for the eye, as the flying city of Columbia, and later on the underwater city of Rapture are very beautiful locations, that require long stares to truly appreciate their beauty. The combat, at least in the original campaign, is a costrated version of the combat from Bioshock 2. Yes you can have both plasmids and guns at the same time, no you can only have two guns on you at a time, or at least until you do the DLC. Combat in the DLC tries to re-capture the Bioshock 2 one, allowing you to have all the weapons on you, using the style of this game's HUDs. Also a major drawback in combat, for me at least, is that different from the first games, weapon upgrades are not visible. I buy a longer clip for my machinegun, and what do I get? the same machinegun with the same clip. Where did the room for 80 more bullets come from? Is it bigger on the inside? It's not that much of a problem, but it's quite a disappointment, for me at least. What do I still have to go over... oh yes, the difficulty! Even on the hardest difficulty the game was fairly easy. Yes, there were a couple places, where I couldn't get pat on my first try, but they were all doable, all thanks to previous preparation, and visiting optional areas. No really, you should really do it. It's better for your own sake.

SPOILERS AHEAD, READ AT OWN RISK!

Lastly, I want to draw this one last comparison to the original Bioshock and Bioshock Infinite. The original Bioshock's story focused highly on Ideology and psychology, especially with the suddent plot twist at the end. It makes you question yourself. Who am I? What ideology is best for me? Am I truly living for myself or am I just somebody's slave? While still having psychological aspects to the plot, Bioshock Infinite focuses more on science(-fiction), racism and battle of the classes, and religion, a little bit. Starting from the end, the religion part comes from the fact that all the opressive, white, rich capitlists are Christians, who believe in American exceptionalism, thinking that the new Noah's ark" is only for them and the other skin colors are there to serve them as lesser humans. While this makes you feel for the "Lesser humans"

Bioshock Infinite is not a game about Christian fundamentalism or race relations or political extremism or expansionist wars. There‚Äôs a little bit of all of those things but not enough to be meaningful or interesting. It‚Äôs rather belittling to the seriousness of the topics that are invoked that nothing is ever done with them. I endured the entirety of this game not caring about anything that happened.

Separate Bioshock Infinite from Ken Levine and Bioshock, and technically it is a fine game. Everything functions properly. Voice acting is OK. Little details in zones means there‚Äôs something cute around every corner. But these sorts of things don‚Äôt make a game a masterpiece. It just means the devs had the time and money.

On top of the muddled storytelling is the rather lackluster ending that gives the impression Levine simply tried to dress up what was already a terrible, half-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• idea with pretentious intellectualism.

I wish I had played the game everyone else seems to be raving about.

reviewText:
This review is more about preference than quality.

This was a tough one for me, as the visuals and presentation were outstanding, but sadly there is a lot wrong with this game, and it's all in the gameplay. I'll start by saying that all of the amazing things shown in the E3 demos was cut for some reason and replaced by more basic and less interesting content.
The game itself is extremely linear run-and-gun, but slower and less convenient. Rather than explore a city, you get locked into small arenas with a circular railway circuit and are forced to fight a number of respawning enemies until a timer runs out and you're allowed to leave.

The complexity of levels is comparable to more faster-paced, more straightforward shooters like Serious Sam, but scaled up in size immensely, which while looks impressive, also means it takes ages to move down pretty basic paths. Exploration involves backtracking miles to find secret buttons or clues, meaning a bad hunch can waste over 20 minutes of walking (which happened to me a few times).

Combat is run-and-gun, but slowed down with combat mechanics that are interesting at first (and I'm sure many gamers would love it), but for me gets jarring and annoying quickly. You get Elizabeth to spawn in infinite ammo boxes, minor barricades or friendly versions of NPCs to distract enemies (and no escape routes or secret passages as previously planned). You then use a basic 'stun' attack with the vigors and then shoot the enemy in their weak spot to kill them, and you have to do this a LOT and the pace of the game gets annoyingly slow as a result. Because you are expected very strongly to use the vigors, the guns are extremely unreliable. To make matters worse, you have only two weapon slots, you can only switch guns with dropped weapons, and ammo can completely vanish in certain areas, with many areas that strongly lean towards specific weapon types- which skews gameplay in many annoying and frustrating ways.

Story was ok-ish, and the presentation of the story was certainly excellent. But again, compared to the trailers, nowhere near as good. The vibrant living atmosphere of a city full of paranoid psychos where Booker tries his best to blend in at his own peril when they could turn on him any minute? Wasn't there. After the opening sequence, the streets are deserted for the rest of the game except for the badguys (police or rebels) waiting to fight you and its a standard first-person shooter. Another problem is the majority of the story is delivered solely via voxophones (audio logs), which are mostly hidden and easily interrupted by scripted character speech, meaning the player must wait for a quiet spot, turn it on, and just sit around listening to it. Some in-world spoken information is easy to miss by being in the wrong place at the wrong time. Overall, it's very easy to miss what is going on.

Overall, it was a pity, as it could have been outstanding, and there is nothing in the game that is legitimately botched or crappy, and to its further credit, the drawbacks I listed were all fairly ambitious ideas and mechanics that I think many people will love (that I simply didn't), and never to poor or unimaginative design that plagues many other games.

If you think an approach like this, or a theatrical experience, is worthwhile in itself, and don't mind the gameplay style, then certainly buy it, if you're like me- maybe not.

reviewText:
This game is heralded as the second coming of Jesus by many. Is it?

Well, no. It's possibly not onlt one of the most overrated games of all time, but probably one of the most boring AAA first person shooters ever released to boot.

The one thing the game has going for it is its phenominal art direction. This is promply ruined by some utterly hillarious character models, props and textures that look like something out of Quake 2. Who needs feet on a cahracter when you can just have flesh coloured matchboxes? Who needs barrels of fruit at a market when you can just have a low resolution texture of fruit put over a polygonal surface? And on top of all this it runs like absolute ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, even on a relatively beefy rig like mine.

Now, what about the gameplay? The grand irony of Bioshock Infinite is that it's heralded as a renaissance from all of those dumb, brainless corridor shooters spat out by big publishers for 12 year old boys, but is in reality unfathomably linear and brainless; more-so than the likes of COD. Enemies are brainless, incompletent bullet sponges who charge toward you like wooden targets for you to effortlessly mow down with your weedy, unsatisfying, royal-free sound effect guns. You might remember the original Bioshock for its ferocious and desperate combat. You won't find that here. You might also remember the brilliant plasmids from Bioshock and the variety they brought to the game. You won't find that here. Well, the plasmids are back (why a society of racial puritans would even think of permanently desecrating their bodies I'll never know (the secret society of crow people being a hillariously bad example which the game never explains)), but I'm not exagerating when I say they all do the exact same thing, just with different, console grade eye candy. One click to stun someone (with an easy instakill if you headshot him), or hold it for a trap (which is useless given the AI). Upgrades all consist of having said effect spread to multiple enemies. You'll probably only ever find yourself using the lightning plasmid.

In addition to all of this, instead of actually, say, balance and design their levels properly, the vast majority of the game will consist of you being unable to find ammo or items, but your parter tossing conveniently needed items in your direction every five seconds. And if that isn't bad enough, the game effectively eliminates any and all challenge by having absolutely no penalty for death. Yes, that's right, if you die, you just carry on as usual. You'll lose some money, but as you'll soon find it's utterly worthless as there's nothing you can spend it on that won't be pelted in your direction the second you need it.

Yet again, this renaissance of the FPS genre is actually even more casualised and patronising than even the dumbest of COD clones. BUT SERIOUSLY, GUYS! IT'S THE GREATEST GAME EVER MADE!

The final thing this game is primarily heralded for is its story. It's an emotional and political tour de force! It sets the standards of storytelling for every game that follows it! Well, I can safely say that's complete and utter ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t.

The game is set in what is initially an enthralling and interesting universe of what is essentially Utah; an isolantionist state of religious puritans all brought together in their love for their prophet, of whom live in absolute luxury on the backs of slave labour and show utter disdain for whom they view as racially inferior. Eventually all hell breaks loose as the underclass revolts in a bloody civil war against their opressors. All the while you are sent to save a girl for a mysterious unexplained reason from this heavenly hellhole, of whom you then have to save.

The universe the game is set in is intially fascinating and deals with what appear to be some great themes; the metamorphasis of religion and government, a post-modernist interpretation of popular revolutions and their fall from grace from the years of hatred the populace has endured. But this is all quickly abandoned in favour of a multiverse plot.

Yes. Alternate universes.

You skip universes so much in the main story line that you wonder what the point in even being attached to anything going on is, as you're ultimately abandoning it five minutes after you even hear about it. And when it does go back to the themes it was obviously supposed to cover but forgot at the last minute, it does so in the most juvenile, brain dead, shallow manner.

OH MY GOD! THEY'RE GOING TO PELT THAT INTERATIAL COUPLE WITH ROTTEN FRUIT!

Well, that's quite literally about as far as the game covers racism. Mississipi Burning, this aint.

OH MY GOD! THE LEADER OF THE REVOLUTION WANTS TO KILL A KID FOR NO APPARENT REASON! THE HORROR!

Animal Farm this isn't.

And to top it all off, it ends in possibly the laziest OMG SO DEEEEP" ending imaginable. You may remember Bioshock's (mostly) incredible ending/final act plot twist that revealed you to simply be a puppet of the game and those offering you guidance; both a great narrative plot twist

reviewText:
First of all I want to start off by saying I am a huge fan of the Bioshock series and fell in love with System Shock a long, long time ago. I can recommend this game if only for the story. This has by far been the most disappointing entry in the series for me. Let's get to the basics shall we?

-Structure: One of the biggest let downs of the title. While there have always been directives and objectives and overall goals sewn into the games, this one follows one core goal to the next in a very linear fashion compared to the others. You have a mission and there isn't any deviating or experimenting afoot, you might have a few instances where you can veer off briefly and grab a new piece of clothing or boost,  but these opportunities are few and far between. You have one autosave checkpoint to the next and if by God for some reason you were to get lost, a simple tap of the up on the Dpad will paint a line showing you where to go next. It's essentially a strict path to follow from one story bullet to the next. 4/10

-Game play: Another disappointing occurrence in what could have been something amazing. The game play in this title is never fully actualized or as fleshed out as it could have been. What you have is a sprawling city atop the clouds and they're all intertwined and connected with these sky-lines. This game could have been as grand and diverse as the original Bioshock but what you essentially get is a connected roller coaster to fly on from one checkpoint to the next. The gun play leaves something to be desired, weapons feel different in their own right but the feeling has been lost from Bioshock. When you would round a corner and see a group of enemies or a Big Daddy and then mentally prepare on how to tackle it. You could lay down some mines or trip wire, stay close to a puddle of water to electrocute your prey and just have a variety of well planned destruction at your disposal. With this game all you really need to do is throw a bronco and or toss some grenades and empty your clip and wait for Elizabeth to toss you another needed resource. 6/10

Presentation: This is where the game really shines and shows that if most things are lost in an Irrational title, they can still tell one hell of a story. What you're presented with is a story that dissects culture as we've come to know. A brainwashed patriotism powered by slavery and a bunch of other somewhat touchy areas throughout history. Racism is thrown up at every corner, and it feels like it fits for an early 1900's era.You can still see some of the overzealous Christian overtones and theme they shove down your throat, for story telling purposes. The graphics are beautiful and colorful with the vivid image of Red, White, and Blue painting the sky and interiors of all the places you'll come to see. While the story crosses into some nonsensical territory, overall it's brought to you in a beautiful way and I expected nothing less. reviewText:
First of all I want to start off by saying I am a huge fan of the Bioshock series and fell in love with System Shock a long, long time ago. I can recommend this game if only for the story. This has by far been the most disappointing entry in the series for me. Let's get to the basics shall we?

-Structure: One of the biggest let downs of the title. While there have always been directives and objectives and overall goals sewn into the games, this one follows one core goal to the next in a very linear fashion compared to the others. You have a mission and there isn't any deviating or experimenting afoot, you might have a few instances where you can veer off briefly and grab a new piece of clothing or boost,  but these opportunities are few and far between. You have one autosave checkpoint to the next and if by God for some reason you were to get lost, a simple tap of the up on the Dpad will paint a line showing you where to go next. It's essentially a strict path to follow from one story bullet to the next. 4/10

-Game play: Another disappointing occurrence in what could have been something amazing. The game play in this title is never fully actualized or as fleshed out as it could have been. What you have is a sprawling city atop the clouds and they're all intertwined and connected with these sky-lines. This game could have been as grand and diverse as the original Bioshock but what you essentially get is a connected roller coaster to fly on from one checkpoint to the next. The gun play leaves something to be desired, weapons feel different in their own right but the feeling has been lost from Bioshock. When you would round a corner and see a group of enemies or a Big Daddy and then mentally prepare on how to tackle it. You could lay down some mines or trip wire, stay close to a puddle of water to electrocute your prey and just have a variety of well planned destruction at your disposal. With this game all you really need to do is throw a bronco and or toss some grenades and empty your clip and wait for Elizabeth to toss you another needed resource. 6/10

Presentation: This is where the game really shines and shows that if most things are lost in an Irrational title, they can still tell one hell of a story. What you're presented with is a story that dissects culture as we've come to know. A brainwashed patriotism powered by slavery and a bunch of other somewhat touchy areas throughout history. Racism is thrown up at every corner, and it feels like it fits for an early 1900's era.You can still see some of the overzealous Christian overtones and theme they shove down your throat, for story telling purposes. The graphics are beautiful and colorful with the vivid image of Red, White, and Blue painting the sky and interiors of all the places you'll come to see. While the story crosses into some nonsensical territory, overall it's brought to you in a beautiful way and I expected nothing less. The shining beacon of light in this game is the story so hang on every word it might be all you have or can take from it. 10/10

Overall I'm not sure what you intend to take from this game, I wanted to love it, I really did but the story is the only basis I can recommend this title for. Your game time will stretch further than a lot of other FPS games will these days but that's it's job, after all it's Bioshock and not Call of Duty. If you bought this on sale you may very well get your money's worth, just see yourself as paying for a really damn good story. Just remember, there's always a lighthouse, there's always a man, and there's always a city. You'll know it when you need to.

reviewText: I've been a gamer since I got my first game system, a Playstation 1, for Christmas nearly 15 years ago. Since then, I have always been drawn to games that were simple, straightforward adventure games that sent a message or told me a story along the way. As gaming has evolved, especially within the past five years, it seems that titles that completely immerse the player in the world the developer created are becoming harder and harder to come by. Bioshock Infinite is one of these rare commodities in a gaming scene dominated by flashy graphics, visceral combat, but no story or atmosphere. The second that I laid eyes on the floating city of Columbia, I knew I had found a rare gem, a diamond in the rough of first person shooters. Atmosphere; that is the word that describes this game through and through. Every scene in the game, every citizen of Columbia oozes it, and this is what keeps the game engaging. I find that it is difficult to really stick with a game if it does not have the atmosphere to initially grab the players attention. While big titles like Assassins Creed or Fallout may have good stories, they still do not have that initial pull that makes the player want to discover more about the world they are playing in. But the game doesn't simply end with atmosphere, not by a long shot. Within the first hour of gameplay, you are flung into a story that, despite the fact that you know nothing about the character you play or why you are in the beautiful city in the sky in the first pace, keeps you hooked. In fact, it may be because of this ignorance that the story is so engaging. The thrill of finding out what lies around the next corner, what may happen to you and your companion as the story unfolds, this is the second beauty of Bioshock Infinite. While the combat and other game mechanics may not be quite as engaging as some other mainstream titles, those things aren't the focus of this game. If you ask me, this lack of focus on gameplay and combat is actually a breath of fresh air. Sure, the combat is engaging enough to be enjoyable at times, but I was glad to see that the developers didn't get caught up in making the rugged, battle worn Booker Dewitt into a second-time veteran, and second-dimension character, but rather spent their efforts making him a fully fleshed-out character, with motives and desires. I will avoid talking about the other characters for the sake of not spoiling the story for those of you who haven't played it, but I will say this: there is a reason this game is my favorite game of all time, and I really hope that this will be yours, too.

reviewText: I've been a gamer since I got my first game system, a Playstation 1, for Christmas nearly 15 years ago. Since then, I have always been drawn to games that were simple, straightforward adventure games that sent a message or told me a story along the way. As gaming has evolved, especially within the past five years, it seems that titles that completely immerse the player in the world the developer created are becoming harder and harder to come by. Bioshock Infinite is one of these rare commodities in a gaming scene dominated by flashy graphics, visceral combat, but no story or atmosphere. The second that I laid eyes on the floating city of Columbia, I knew I had found a rare gem, a diamond in the rough of first person shooters. Atmosphere; that is the word that describes this game through and through. Every scene in the game, every citizen of Columbia oozes it, and this is what keeps the game engaging. I find that it is difficult to really stick with a game if it does not have the atmosphere to initially grab the players attention. While big titles like Assassins Creed or Fallout may have good stories, they still do not have that initial pull that makes the player want to discover more about the world they are playing in. But the game doesn't simply end with atmosphere, not by a long shot. Within the first hour of gameplay, you are flung into a story that, despite the fact that you know nothing about the character you play or why you are in the beautiful city in the sky in the first pace, keeps you hooked. In fact, it may be because of this ignorance that the story is so engaging. The thrill of finding out what lies around the next corner, what may happen to you and your companion as the story unfolds, this is the second beauty of Bioshock Infinite. While the combat and other game mechanics may not be quite as engaging as some other mainstream titles, those things aren't the focus of this game. If you ask me, this lack of focus on gameplay and combat is actually a breath of fresh air. Sure, the combat is engaging enough to be enjoyable at times, but I was glad to see that the developers didn't get caught up in making the rugged, battle worn Booker Dewitt into a second-time veteran, and second-dimension character, but rather spent their efforts making him a fully fleshed-out character, with motives and desires. I will avoid talking about the other characters for the sake of not spoiling the story for those of you who haven't played it, but I will say this: there is a reason this game is my favorite game of all time, and I really hope that this will be yours, too.

reviewText:
BioShock Infinite is by no means a terrible game, but compared to its predecessor, it has many of the same flaws and lacks the redeeming poetry and vision.

BioShock is now a modern classic. Its successor, BioShock Infinite, takes us to a new world that is superficially just as captivating as Rapture, but the similarities are purely superficial. Where BioShock had ideas, Infinite simply has plot devices. Where BioShock asked us to choose, Infinite just asks us to run and shoot.

Part of what made BioShock special was that its ideas, emotions, story content, and gameplay were all coherent in a thematically consistent way. Ultimately BioShock told a story that was thematically compatible, and even thematically harmonious, with the conceits and conventions of FPS games. BioShock Infinite tries to tell a story, but the dissonance between the narrative/emotional content and the gameplay content is jarring in the new installment. It doesn't help that the story, though told with exquisite craft and care, ultimately is for all its artistry utterly inane.

With a story that is so thoroughly undermined by the gameplay mechanics, Infinite needs to lean heavily on gameplay to be entertainment. Unfortunately, like BioShock, Infinite is merely a competent shooter from a gameplay perspective. Worse, the level designs are now more linear.

In sum, it's a competent but underwhelming game, and outright disappointing when set against its predecessor.

reviewText:
With imagination ranging from underwater cities to floating cities built high above the clouds, Irrational Games and parent company 2K never disappoint.

Bioshock Infinite sports a new unique combination of fast paced, rollercoaster, shooter gameplay. On top of the innovative gameplay Irrational and 2K do an exceptional job of creating beautiful environments, and constructing a polished narrative and pulling off an excellent story. Infinite might bear a lot of differences compared to its predecessors in the Bioshock franchise, but the story and atmosphere is the icing on the cake. Infinite‚Äôs Inception-esque conclusion will have players on the edge of their computer chairs and then continue on to blow their minds.

Overall Irrational and 2K, as always worked up an amazing title worthy of winning many game of the year awards. Not incorporating an excessively fun completive or cooperative multiplayer modes are the only gripes that comes to mind. Not to worry. Due to excellent DLC releases I think Bioshock Infinite has the potential to keep audiences hooked and wanting more of Columbia for quite some time. Bioshock Infinite comes neck and neck with its original predecessor in this outstanding series.

If you‚Äôre looking for a great single player experience with stellar visuals, and some of the best story telling the videogame market has to offer, don‚Äôt pass up a chance to enjoy Bioshock Infinite! A+

reviewText: Had loads of fun with this game. Everything is beautifully crafted, especially the set designs that come in a huge variety but all remain fresh and equally interesting. As with the original Bioshock, the intricate presentation of social themes and ideologies are an important part of the overarching design, and Bioshock Infinite is no different. They are gripping and clearly presented, while refraining from distracting the player from the main narrative. The story, while confusing and even overbearing at times, is intriguing, reaching a fascinating crescendo during the last 20 minutes of the game.\n\nThe game is by no means 'perfect', but the clear amount of affection and care that has been put into every small detail in all of its many, many different components results in something that is thoroughly remarkable and enjoyable. It's a game that should be respected, and more importantly enjoyed, for a sum of all its parts.

reviewText:
5/10

While fun was had, the game was mediocre overall. Just because I had fun doesn't mean others should look for it in a dissappointing game.

Pros:
-Artistic Direction was great.
-Sound/VA very well done.
-Skyrails make fights more interesting than previous bioshocks.

Cons:
-Story was convoluted and generally bad. It doesn't explore the difficult situations that it presents, and roughly halfway through the game the plot dissappears due to multiverse theory. The ending only exacerbates the muddy storytelling.
-The choices made in game were pointless.
-Voxophones were nowhere near as interesting as audio diaries or audio logs.
-Characterization of Comstock, Fink, Fitzroy, Slate, etc. just fall flat compared to Ryan, Fontaine, Cohen, Steinman, or even Delacroix, Polito, Shodan, and Xerxes.
-While we're on the subject Elizabeth was not very well done either.
-Corridor shooter.
-Not enough Skyrails, and conceptually they make no sense.
-2 gun limit.
-Shields for no reason.
-Vigors overly similar in terms of utility.
-No hacking or Research Camera.
-Enemies lack variety.
-Difficulty was implemented poorly, giving enemies more health just makes playing tedious.

reviewText:
Jack of all trades, master of none.

Bioshock infinite is a shooter based on the existing franchise, however the gameplay felt poorly planned.  The firefights were uninspired bouts of you against massive bullet sponges.  There is little incentive to use your elemental powers as the enemies are easily defeated without.  The combat seems to encourage the use of cover, however it lacks a key component: usable cover.  Each fight is approached the same way, and although the game lets you use your powers to place traps, you will almost never find yourself in a place to use them.  Each fight is a head-on bout of how many bullets of your seemingly infinite supply it will take to progress in the story.

speaking of the story, it has no focus.  In the beginning, it is a portrayal of a society in the clouds full of religious bigotry and racism.  It soon turns into a completely pointless display of how much Ken Levine knows about theoretical physics, apparently just enough to think he knows what he's doing when he has really only scratched the surface.  Although at times interesting, by the end it does not make sense with itself and still baffles the community and even Levine himself.  The story will leave you feeling empty, as it makes no remark on the social injustice happening in columbia.

The game tries to do too many stories and fails to complete them effectively, making the whole game feel both unguided and lazily put together.  If there was a more clear direction as to where they wanted to go with the story, it would have been at least redeemable in that aspect.  The gameplay should be completely revamped, as the actual first-person-shooter aspect is neither fun nor rewarding.  Every weapon uninspired, every special ability almost pointless to use.

Bioshock: Infinite gets a 2/5

reviewText:
Well, although  not the best game in the universe, this game does both right and wrong things all at the same time. The main complaint I have with BioShock Infinite are its two contrasting themes of parallel dimensions mixed in with themes of religiousism, idolfication, the constitution of the United States of America, sexism, hedonism and people in black sheep's clothing, it does too much. There is no separate transition from this main theme towards the other themes of tears, parallel dimensions Elizabeth can will by the power of her memories.  If this was removed the game would be so much better.

Let's get down to the breakdown of the game.

Gameplay: Gameplay as others have mentioned I am sure already is the repetitive gunplay. There are many situations where you are forced through the in-game script to pick-up weapons you may not want to use in the situations they make you use them in. This is problematic in one of the toughest battles later in the game against warships, zepplins. The guns however do feel nice to use. The sounds of them might be a little unrealistic or barely noted to pay attention to.

Story:
This is my largest complaint with the game , even more so then the repetitive gameplay without much variation. Much of the game is told through kinetoscopes which tell majority of the story through a type of film projected roll of film in black-white old cinematic style. However, the story is better presented through non-verbal actions when you meet Elizabeth and when she interacts with you within the world she was trapped in. However, you as an outsider don't understand everything that Elizabeth understands and knows about the world in which she lives in as an insider. This is why they had to put parallel dimensions in this game to make sense of both an insider and outsider perspective of the situations at hand. However, it is poorly executed and done.

Religion:     Many of you that are not religous or even Christian for that matter will not understand some of the biblical references to the garden of eden, Sodom of Gomorrah and washing away the debt of sins. However, without spoiling the story too much, one guy comes to you and says you can wash away the debt of your sins if you give your own daughter away; though, it is really unclear if it is yours or Elizabeth when she was a girl. I assumed it was Elizabeth since she is the one they wanted to take Lady Comstock's place in the end .

Themes:

Idolfication: The story takes place in the early 1900's. There are points in the game where you enter in upon factory workers being enslaved and  people are  being tortured for heresy against a rising secular cult of people that are not following the true Gospel of God. Everyone in this game is blinded by idolfication. Even the people who follow Comstock, they are just his followers; nothing more. He is the actual false prophet in the game, though they frame you as the AntiChrist when instead you play the role of Jesus. Your job is not to minister to people but to tell them that they are wrong about following this skeptical guy Comstock and his teachings. He is the one that actually should be accused of heresy. However, during this time, Columbia is promised an eternal state of Heaven. However, they believe it has to be done through a human sacrifice of Elizabeth through the baptism of Booker De Witt.

Racisim: They have black and white wash stations characteristic of slavery days. There are various jargon and little things I will not be going over as that would spoil the game's experience for you. Take note that there is much racisim and questions regarding the philosophies of the world along with branding people's names of the last sins they have commited upon death. If it takes place in the 1900's sins should be wiped away through Jesus Christ. Ultimately they believe Booker is the AntiChrist. Yet in many parallel dimensions he is seen as the hero and savior of the world of Columbia.

Overall: Do I think Christians should play this game though it stands as one of the most controversial triple AAA games out there currently in the bounds of the Christian worldview and modern world? Yes I think you should. This game teaches you what the nation is like and the times we live in today with modernisim using parallel dimensions and universes as the main driving point and vehicle for the message. It shows you both the good and bad things of religion. What works right when religion is performed in a manner based on biblical teachings, then what goes wrong when those biblical teachings are reprimanded when man's leadership is based on the teachings of our country's founders.

6/10 Only because many games don't have the courage to discuss idolfication, racisim, sexism and politics in a worldly sphere and through alternative realities relating to the secular realities of men and women on this earth. Even though the game is just your average shooter, it is worth at least for you to check it out for yourself.

reviewText:
BioShock Infinite has lofty ambitions. It tries to tackle some social and existential questions, provide entertaining gameplay, and wrap it all up in an emotionally moving package. Unfortunately, the game's polish belies its shallow depth.

The gunplay brings absolutely nothing new to the table. While the addition of Sky-Lines was an interesting idea, the implementation reduces it mostly to a form of locomotion, rather than a primary form of combat. The game provides challenge through tough, not intelligent enemies, especially on later difficulties where several headshots may be necessary for a simple grunt.

As for the story, it attempts to bring in elements of multiverse theory and explores ideas of choice and consequence for each of the characters in the game. However, in doing so, it contradicts itself several times over in its conclusion. I won't spoil that here; there are several videos you can watch to see the ending, along with interpretations if you wish.

While the game paints a pretty picture and plays a few nice tunes, it fails to sufficiently answer many of the questions the early portions will give you. What one is left with, then, is contradictions and loose threads, and the game provides very little to alleviate these issues.

reviewText:
Despite this game receiving a majority of popular feedback, I find it falls very short as a game. I do however feel that it is a fantastic piece of art. The environments are gorgeous, and exploring Colombia were rather enjoyable. Also the story was well told and quite moving despite some gaps in continuity. However that's the extent of its positive qualities.

As game it fails to be challenging, even on Hard mode the combat is incredibly trivial. Elizabeth can keep you feed with an infinite supply of ammo, health, and salts, which you don't even need because you can just kill everything with the skyhook. Aside from the combat the game was incredibly linear, with very few secrets, and of those that did exist none really provided any substantial benefit because the combat was so easy to begin with.

And again back to the problems with it being so linear, I can't help but compare it to the first Bioshock, which was also linear, however at least had multiple endings. With Bioshock: Infinite there is one ending, and honestly it's not that good. For a game that has a theme of infinite worlds with infinite possibilities you have only one ending? Really?

To sum it all up it's just not a good game; like I said the story was pretty good, but the combat is poor, and the player cannot change the outcome of the ending. In terms of gameplay it's more like Myst or Riven than a shooter. It's just a beautiful enviornment to explore. However, unlike Myst or Riven, Bioshock: Infinate is devoid of any choice or challenge. Overall I'd have to say that you would probably be better off just watching all the cutscenes on youtube, because it would make a better movie than a game.

Every time you encounter a Big Daddy instantly what came to my mind was "Awwww ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t. Here we go!". But in Infinite honestly it was NOTHING like the older games. Your wandering around a bright city killing random soldiers and every day people. Nothings even remotely suspenseful or similar to the first 2 games in any way shape or form. There are no Big roaming sort of bosses like in the first 2 with Big Daddies.

It's basically just arena gameplay which I never played Call of Duty but it definitely felt like a generic shooter. Just run into an area and start shooting. You can clearly see they lost any element of suspense with the ridiculous introduction of a damn shield. That completely ruins any aspect of surprise because if someone catches me off guard who cares..... It didn't break through my shield and actually hurt me. What's worse is everythings shared through just generic money. Want to upgrade your powers? Use money..... Want to upgrade that weapon? Use money. I can rant forever but it's just.... .... not Bioshock. The story tries to be clever and almost mirror the events of the first game in a vague sense. But the story is just generic and kind of pretentious."

reviewText:
A remarkable story that puts the Bioshock franchise in a place where anything can happen next and everything from the series were placed together.

Deep and engaging characters, astonishing visuals and a truly rich backstory fulfilled with a mixture of history and fantasy, covering aspects of our society like the struggle of social classes or religion and state exploit, make one of the best games of all time.

Bugs at the beginning, some boring mechanics, unjustified excessive violence, bad design/budget decisions, the well known millions of chain quests covering the same places over and over, and mostly the unbelievable absence of a decent save system almost ruin the game or make it average, but the good points are just awesome and hold Bioshock Infinite like an awesome, over the top game.

It's a good mix of action and story - entertainment and art excellence.

reviewText:
So beautiful, so incredibly flawed everywhere else.

I really enjoy the visuals and asthetics of the game but it tries too hard to be insightful. Its a discussion about history and politics written by someone who took a 100 level college class and likes to argue at parties. It's an -interesting- world but none of it makes any sense no matter how you try to suspend your disbelief.

It's not an awful game, the production is AAA quality as one would expect. It's just shallow and soulless beyond its beautiful facade. I keep asking myself, Why are these people shooting at me?" and I literally never have an asnwer. Furthermore the system to direct you tothe nect objective will literally run you in a never ending circle and provide you aboslutely no direction as to how to proceed in the game.

Why are these people shooting at me? Where am I supposed to go? Why is plot consistancy so hard? Why can't anyone make a twist ending in a videogame that actually makes any sense without ignoring absolutely everything that happened in the entire game?"

reviewText: After letting this game stew for a while, I find my opinion has worsened from even my lackluster feelings after beating the game. Before you begin in with cries of you don't get it or you can't compare it to bioshock, I will bisect those two arguments right here and now. First off, yes, I may have missed bits of the subtext but I understood what was going on and it was a bit of a mess. Being pretentious does not mean being misunderstood, it means pretending to be making points and being smarter than you are, and this game is not nearly as intelligent or interwoven as it would like you to think it is. Secondly, yes I can compare it to bioshock because its called bioshock infinite, has psuedo-plasmids and similar combat and even blanketly steals sound assets from the first. The very name invited the comparison and therefore invites criticism regarding that. Now with that out of the  way, no I would not reccomend this game at full price, though at a sale price I can reccomend it for a playthrough at least. The game squanders its potential by not focusing on the more interesting bits, like talking to citizens and exploring the town with dull combat, that is infinitely more boring than Bioshock. Theres no real sense of progression, the fights are just long and drawn out and the abilities are mostly uninterestinhg or just copies of the original games plasmids. And speaking on that, the vigors are just reskinnned plasmids, just without any of the lore, intrigue or even real relation to the universe that Bioshock and even a game that I consider in some ways to be better, Bioshock 2 had. reviewText:
To quote someone else, Bioshock Infinite is wasted potential.

The art deco, like Bioshock, is amazing. But, just like Bioshock again, any topics they bring up like racism for example has no commentary or explanation for it which is just bad. This is because it makes the setting and characters feel shallow, and because commentary and explanation can be interesting and informative in it's own right.

The interactions between Booker and Elizabeth are interesting and will probably keep you engage enough to see the story to the end, but most of the game is bad shoot people gameplay.

People will argue that the gameplay is bad because B:I got rid of basically all the RPG elements in Bioshock and also made the map design completely linear, but I disagree with this. These people don't remember that Bioshock already had shallow RPG mechanics and poor map design. The maps were design so that each path was a deadend that the player had to backtrack through once a mission was done... instead of making things loop around. This happens in B:I still, but the linearity negates most of it to optional missions.

In B:I the vigors (plasmids) nearly all do the same thing (LMB to attack, RMB to make a trap) removing any strategy on which one to choose and removing any reason to mix them together (which atleast Bioshock had). You also can only hold 2 weapons, which ruins any chance of mixing up the gameplay. Like you have limited resources so you have to choose wisely on what weapons to upgrade so you'll probably only hold the same 2 weapons you've upgraded through the game because if you upgraded a 3rd weapon you won't be able to use it unless you randomly find it on the ground in the middle of the fight.

Also since you don't have an inventory Elizabeth will randomly throw you items that you need during a fight which means there isn't really any strategy to refilling your health/magic in the middle of combat. Yes there are items that have small refilling benefits but that doesn't replace potions. You also can buy refill potions that are applied instantly and also random refill areas in combat arenas so just abuse these locations?

But while they basically stripped down the gameplay to a bare FPS minimum, I think it was a step in the right direction for these developers. But they needed to go one step further, remove the gameplay entirely. Seriously, if this was a Themepark Simulator there would have been more time to flesh out the narrative, characters, and setting which the game greatly needed.

I played the game on medium and I would not recommend playing it on higher difficulties because there are bullet sponge enemies and the only boss fight in the game is a bullet sponge that infinitely spawns enemies in which you fight the boss multiple times.

I can't recommend this game because of the poor gameplay. I would recommend instead watching an LP (Let's Play or Long Play depending on your perspective c;) and buying some cool looking merchandise from Irrational Games instead https://store.irrationalgames.com/

reviewText:
I'm a Bioshock fan and I've been looking forward to play this... I finally got my hands on it but just didn't want to believe what I've seen...

Two weapon limit and combat mechanics just feel wrong. Enemies are way too precise and feel non-human. Combat feels rushed and hectic. Enemy dialogs are repeatative and annoying. Resources are too tight which makes the scavenge around most of the time instead of focusing on the atmosphere. Elizabeth does help you with ammunition however it does become annoying when she interrupts the combat to throw coins and salts and ammo at you...

graphics are good... however if you want to explore Columbia more you'll have invisible boundaries blocking you.

So far [after 9 hours] story is also really predictable. Also the NPCs around you almost don't respond to you at all. They all look and act like bunch of robots...

To sum up after the first two Bioshock games this game is a BIG DISAPPOINTMENT. I just don't understand how this game attracts more attention and better reviews than first two. Save your money for some other game...

EDIT:
I've just played it through, I must admit that the story did get better than at the beginning (very good ending), however I still find the first two games of the franchise better. Weapons and plasmids were much more fun to use. Combat felt right and fair. And the storytelling was better than in Bioshock Infinite. Instead of a weak start and a good end they were consistently good.
It's sad to see one of my favourite games becoming something so dull...

reviewText:
Game started out fantastic. Beautiful design, engaging themes, and entertaining situations. Fast forward to around the sixth hour of gameplay: redundant fights, annoying combat, unsatisfying powers, and (if playing on the highest difficulty) maddeningly frustrating fights with the Handyman. Seriously, if you disagree with me, try to beat the Handyman in one of the last fights on the hardest difficulty. There is nothing gratifying with the combat structure in this game.

Most reviews that I see gush over the game's story. Look, I get it: the idea of alternate universes, travel between them, and consequences of choices that can alter future choices is intriguing. Unfortunately, getting to these themes involved introducing multiple, underdeveloped characters that just seemed like more and more names being thrown at you. The games storyline with the revolution and the overall alternate universes" theme conflicted and annoyed me for the latter part of the game. Fighting animated patriot machines was... dumb. It seemed like the developers felt they could get away with putting any stupid scenario in the game just because in one of the infinite universes it was possible.

I would recommend many other games over Bioshock Infinite. I strongly feel that its success is a product of strong advertising. Not GOTY in terms of atmosphere

I can't recommend this game -

Don't get me wrong, the art style and story are great, the gameplay is challenging and the game is fun, overall.

If you can play it for more than 5 minutes at a time.

I wish I'd done some research before buying, but Google search results and Steam's support forum don't lie - there's a world of hurt awaiting a lot of random people that try to play this game, primarily in the form of direct to desktop crashes after random periods of time in-game.

I'm no newb to troubleshooting hardware, drivers and software issues, but nothing has worked for me, although your mileage may vary.  2K Games is basically ignoring anyone that reports this issue, unfortunately.  It's really a shame, because the game makes me want to finish it, but I can't stand replaying the same parts over and over, hoping to hit a save checkpoint before the next crash.

So, long story short, it's buggy and basically unplayable for me.  It might work just fine for you, but if I'd known so many people were having issues with it, I'd have spent my money elsewhere.

BioShock Infinite is the game I regret buying more than any other in my collection. It makes me wish that tears in spacetime really existed so I could warn myself NOT to preorder it. The gameplay is boring, the story feels poorly written and rushed, and the graphics are woefully inconsistent.

The original BioShock was a very in-depth game where strategy was key. This game is a Call of Duty clone with a steampunk setting and the BioShock name slapped on.

I do not recommend this game to anyone, for any price. Avoid at all costs!

Most people seem to praise this game for it's story. However, the story itself is unfocused, doesn't push any limits, and uses the timeframe poorly. The parts about quantum physics also make little sense and seem to written by somebody who has no understanding of the science behind it.

reviewText:
Very few games move me enough to have me consider a second play through. BioShock Infinite is one of those games. From the story to the combat, I have enjoyed every last second of the Columbia experience. Please don't compare this to previous games with similar titles... and as such I will not compare them in this recommendation. What I will do is explain what I love about Infinite, and if it jives with what you also love in games, then you will enjoy this experience as well.

For one, without any spoilers, the story is tremendous. Not Dickens or Shakespeare, but for Sci-Fi fans who enjoy stories that try to stretch the imagination, this definitely satisfies.

Columbia itself is nicely fleshed-out with a lot of details. It's nice to see a city that is seemingly pleasant until you see the underlying fanaticism and bigotry. It is almost uncomfortable and off-putting, but makes the experience that much more real.

Besides story and setting, the remaining piece would be combat, of which I found quite satisfying. If you're not a fan of bullet-spongy baddies you've definitely come to the wrong place. I played through on Hard the first time, and the game definitely gave me a challenge. With only two weapons to swap between and a limited amount of Salt for Vigors (read Plasmids), I had to be very careful. It was easy to get myself killed by running out into the open; movement and cover is key.

Most of the weapons are satisfying although at first I was a bit confused by the red and blue ammo (each faction has similar weapons with their own sets of ammo); I think subsequent play-throughs I will focus on upgrading a handful of specific ones instead of spreading myself so thin.

As far as Vigors are concerned, I have to admit I enjoyed some more than others. While many where useful, when I eventually got Return to Sender" and "Bucking Bronco"

reviewText: Going to try reviewing this again now that I gave it a fair shot and played it to completion. Long story short: It's still not good in any particular way. It looks and plays rather dated. The game is meanspirited, ugly and not as immersive or intelligent as it likes to pretend it is. Almost everything it does well another game or story does better. Want chaotic shoot and loot gameplay with customizable upgrades with oddly frequent vending machines? Borderlands 2 is all that but non-linear. Want to delve into an immersive dystopia presented in a linear fashion? Try Dishonored. Want trippy pandimensional storytelling that doesn't take itself too seriously? There's a lot of good anime like that, try Steins;Gate. Bioshock Infinite isn't bad but it is mediocre and tiresome, practically presented like a Halo level that threatens to never end. On the plus side, if religious racist political zealots grind your gears the game does serve as a nice anger outlet, but I wouldn't pay more than $15 for the whole thing including DLC. It does have a few neat characers like the Lutece twins that are worth seeing, but they're not enough to salvage the game.

reviewText:
Best game I ever played, and I played most of them, if not all.

I started playing, and I didn't stop until the final scene. It took me 13 hours, and I took it SLOWLY but what an insane game.

The scenery and atmosphere is straight out of a psychedelic trip, i can't even describe it.

The story is so deep it will leave you thinking for weeks, and the research the developers must have put into this is just breathtaking.

The music is spot on, and i often found myself just abusing the ingame radios to replay songs. Voice acting flawless aswell.

Even the characters are so well crafted, to the point where you can feel their personalities, very rare imho.

Usually when I play FPS games, its for the combat the action and so on. But in this game, the combat actually anoyyed me, cus it meant that i didn't get any lore, that i didn't get to explore and feel the game.

Throughout my entire playthrough i didn't encounter a single bug, i didn't have to restart the game once and not even a visual bug was to be found.

And if you think you're a hardcore player, you can just play on hard, and i promise you it will be a challenge even for the top skilled.

If I have to compare this to other games, i would say Half-life 1 with a stronger story, and much more atmosphere minus the puzzles.

This is a standalone game, the story really doesn't overlap with bioshock 1/2, and you can easily play this without playing the others. Definetely the best in the series.

Best game I played nuff said.

reviewText:
The combat in this game was pretty fun.  It was fresh and exciting, at least at first. The skylines were fun to zip around and made for some challenging fast paced combat. The amount of detail that went into building this new world to explore was insane. It had a distinctive voice of it's own but still fit in with the rest of the franchise very nicely.

However, I did find the gameplay to get a bit repetitive towards the end. There wasn't a whole lot of strategy that went into the combat and I found I could stumble through any encounter without too much thought. I also just didn't care for the story much, this could just be me but,  it felt like they just kept dragging on the ending for eternity and it made the last two hours or so of gameplay horrifically boring. I understand in this genre of story telling that its intentional to leave a lot questions unanswered and have the audience wondering just what exactly they experienced but, it just felt poorly executed in the long run.

In general, I'd say I would've felt better if I had perhaps rented this rather then spend the forty bucks on it. I don't regret playing it but, I just wasn't terribly impressed and probably won't play it again.
