reviewText:
(Mostly spoiler free)

When all's said and done, a fairly disappointing game. The gameplay is certainly subpar, with lots of elements removed from previous titles. There is a nicely large variety of weapons, but this is completely undermined by the utterly unnecessary two weapons limit, which serves only to stifle player choice and undermine the upgrade system as well. Enemy variation isn't much to write home about. The regenerating shield is the first time that regenerating health has been tried in this series, and unfortunately really hurts the combat, since it makes cowering behind boxes and popping out to fire one of the most effective combat tactics. Also the only boss fights which occur in this game are terrible. Not just hard, but horribly designed: infinitely respawning enemies, limited weapons and a bullet sponge boss, with money deducted and enemy health restored every time you die.

The story starts off quite strongly, although as more of the plot is revealed, plot holes spring up all over the place and the conclusion is confusing, rife with its own plot holes and unsatisfying. The world is also poorly constructed, with the player murdering hundreds of innocent people for the crime of being law enforcement officers, then continuing to have normal conversations with Elizabeth, making Booker seem completely insane. Vigors are an adapation of plasmids from earlier games, but while plasmids were integral to the plot in Bioshock, vigors are very much an afterthought, with basically no bearing on how the city operates.

Elizabeth as a character is confusing. She has spent her whole life locked up in a tower, yet seems to be normally socially adjusted, which seems unusual. As a gameplay element, she is strangely shoehorned in. She cannot be injured or captured by enemies, who will completely ignore her, and can occasionally find" ammo

reviewText:
Bioshock Infinite is an extraordinary game. The story it tells through it's main characters, DeWitt and Elizabeth, is so engaging and surprisingly well put together, you will find yourself incredibly immersed. If you're anything like me, you won't be able to take a break. It is an amazing adventure, as well as a suspenseful mystery, that all comes together in its final moments to form an incredibly solid ending. It will leave you with many questions, but only a very small number that can't be answered by another play-through or a few more minutes of thought. All of this paired with it's polished look, and smooth feel makes it a must have for... Well. Everyone.

One final note: I'd recommend using a gamepad to maximize the experience. Some of the controls using a keyboard and mouse, even with customization, have some seemingly unavoidable non-intuitiveness to them. That's my opinion, anyway.

Enjoy!

reviewText:
BLEW MY MIND!!

The game itself is linear, bog standard gunplay, generic guns. Plasmids, plasmid upgrades and weapon upgrades whilst helpful play no bearing on progress or the style in which you would attempt to play through the game. This isn't the spiritual successor to System Shock 2, it's not even the spiritual seccessor to Bioshock, it's a Shock game in name only in my opinion...rapture references, plasmids, steampunk and noir stylings notwithstanding.

It excels however in storytelling, serving up an experience drenched in art and design stylings which are arguably as good as it gets. This is flanked by one of the best looking and best optimised engines I think I've seen of late. Cities in the clouds, beeches, shantytowns, factories, Rapture are all brought to life with vibrant lighting and visual effects. Every scene is a picture postcard, breathing.....alive.

Small moments in game such as when you first meet Elizabeth. She's painting a picture of the Eiffel tower in France but after pondering the results of her picture instead decides to open a tear" in space and time and as you look through the "tear" Tears for Fears can be heard blaring amongst the background hustle and bustle of a Parisian street
date: Return of the Jedi is shown as playing at a cinema on said street. Bioshock Infinite overflows with moments such as this and the result is that it elevates a fairly average
hoursPlayed: involving experience.\n\nThe ending pretty much cements any positive opinions I had on the game

reviewText: I enjoyed this game, in a broad sense, but I recognize that there's a lot wrong with it. I think the game's strongest point is its story with the visuals at a close second- unfortunately, gameplay is far behind. Combat is largely Bioshock in that you face a number of uninteresting fights saddled with a poor combat engine, slowly whittling down a huge number of HP-sponge enemies. It's unfortunate that the story is punctuated by the lackluster combat, because it just makes the actual gameplay a hurdle to be skipped over in persuance of the next tidbit of story progression. It's quite an interesting story, dealing with multiple universes and how it all combines in 1912 America. The visuals are superb, and the flying city is the perfect setting to show off the engine. Unfortunately I think the city itself is the dumbest part of the game. Where Bioshock 1's Rapture was a nuanced, living place, Columbia is alternately filled with Tea Party racists and OOGITY BOOGITY leftist caricatures. Note: It's not good writing to make everything so extreme as to be ridiculous. The ending is the laziest piece of writing I've experienced in many years and makes the game completely worse for it. I can't really recommend this game, except to a Bioshock fan.

reviewText:
Had this game on Ps3 when it came out, and found it very indulging in story to the point where I may have spent a bit too much time playing it over and over for a week straight. The gameplay is just your average FPS variant due to the combination of guns and special powers called vigors that work in a similar way to plasmids from the first 2 games. The story is a fairly average one until you get more towards the end of the game where it finally all hits you and mind****s the hell out of you, and I did thoroughly enjoy it. Whilst the twist may not have had the same impact as the first Bioshock's twist did, it still was pretty much unseen for the most part and is worthy of appreciation as much as the first game was.

If you have played the first 2 games, I think you will really enjoy this one. In my personal opinion I would put it ahead of Bioshock 2, but behind the original Bioshock, yet still a game worthy of the hype it received. If you like to play games based on the gameplay, and you're looking for a very good FPS, this MIGHT fit the bill but I would recommend it far more for the immersive story, the connections that can be made to the old Bioshocks, and the refreshing colour tones it brings for most of the game. (Oh - And of course all the crazy fan theories people come up with).

Very enjoyable and well worth the download. Personal verdict - 9.5/10.

reviewText: Bioshock Infinite plot begins with our protagonist going in a mission to rescue a girl that has been held captive in an utopiac city over the clouds. First thing you'll notice once you get there is the stunning beauty of the colourful visuals. You can see Irrational games put a lot of work into this, and it continues all through the game until the very ending. Next is the OST, I wouldn't say outstanding, but rather fitting. Combat is fast paced, and fun, especially when using the sky lines. There's room for strategy, but it's not a tactical shooter, cover and shoot will get you out of almost any situation even in the Hard difficulty. The story is the strongest point of the game, not much is reveled until the end, but you'll probably figure out things and make theories on your own. It reminded me of Chrono Cross, but don't worry, it doesn't get that complicated.\nAs drawbacks, I experienced performance issues even though I'm roughly over the recommended requirements, the lack of a multiplayer to add play time, the low difficulty (Passed it swiftly in hard) and poor enemy AI. Playthrough time is 11-13 hours.\nGreat shooter, absolutely recommended: 8,2/10

reviewText:
THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE BIOSHOCK INFINITE DLC, BURIAL AT SEA EPISODE 2. THIS IS NOT A REVIEW OF BIOSHOCK INFINITE.

This is without a doubt the best DLC I've ever played. I liked Burial at Sea Episode 2 more than BioShock Infinite itself. Maybe the reason why I enjoyed this so much is because I'm a huge fan of the original BioShock, but at the same time I really liked Elizabeth's character and the way she interacted with characters from the original game.

The Schrodinger's Cat stuff is still present due to this being an expansion of BioShock Infinite's story. This doesn't really bother me, though, seeing as the story is presented in a way where the player can actually take a moment to digest everything that's been happening - as opposed to BioShock Infinite. I'm not into the whole multiple dimensions thing, but if I absolutely had to have a story with it - this is how I'd want it done.


Pros
- Stealth combat that feels fresh after BioShock and BioShock Infinite's manic gunplay.
- A plot that isn't as hard to swallow as BioShock Infinite's.
- Great atmosphere - fans of the original BioShock will love it.
- A couple new vigors/plasmids are introduced for the first time.
- A great wrap-up to BioShock Infinite and a fantastic prequel for the original BioShock.
- Sheds light on a few previously unseen areas and factoids of Rapture.


Cons
- The plot can seem kind of far out sometimes.
- Plot holes, depending on how hard you want to look.
- The Peeping Tom plasmid can kind of break the game's stealth mechanics.
- The fact that the game tries to push you into playing stealthily as opposed to all guns blazing.
- Going back to Colombia.
- I wish it were longer!


Overall, this is an amazing DLC that is definitely worth the admission fee. If you liked the first BioShock and didn't care too much for Infinite, this is basically a love letter to you from Irrational Games. Would you kindly kick back and enjoy your return to Rapture?

A Stunning Tour de Force and A Satisfying Conclusion to the Bioshock Saga

I played the original Bioshck back in 2008, it was a game of both great gameplay and artistic design, while the first game certainly raised the bar for the industry, the second one was more or less a letdown for me, although a decent game on its own. However, when it comes to the third game, Bioshock Infinite, the developer has done a great job to bring the series back to its full glory.

Graphics: 9/10
The world in Colombia never lacks breathtaking beauty, whether it is in peaceful sightseeing or under brutal combat situation, I can't help but stop to admire the city in the clouds at times, it's all you can imagine in a lost fairytale.
At first glance, the city is vivid with people murmuring and birds flying, as you discover more truth, the environment shifts yet continues to impress you. There might be blocky props here and there if you care about the smallest detail, but it's clear that the developer tries to maintain the best balance between image quality and good performance.
All in all, Colombia seen from the Skyline is always the city seen for the first time

reviewText:
This game is incredible.

In terms of gameplay it offers a fair variety of guns and vigors. Some vigors are better implemented than others, the shock jockey and murder of crows being some of the more useful. The game also adds than extra layer of depth in the form of environmental hazards such as oil spills and Elizabeth's tears providing friendly covering fire or simply health/ammo points. These help the game feel fresh in an industry over populated with FPS games.

This game excels unlike any other when it comes down to its beautifully crafted world with its own unique art style. It is truly breathtaking at points. You could spend hours just wondering around it in without killing a single soul if you choose as the world is immersive.

The storyline itself is as engaging experience that needs to be experienced first hand. You learn more about both your own character and te character of Elizabeth as the game progresses but the game creates more questions than answers which enables the story to remain intense throughout. For a game with no real cut scenes and that is as first person as they come really to be so engaging is an achievement just by itself. The developers have done an incredible job here. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
EDIT*** - See below for the solution to the constant freezing I was having with this game.

Trying to get this game to run on my rig gave me diarrhea.  Evidently, this installment isn't too fond of overclocked graphic cards.  Let me say, short of taking my card back to manufacturer default I tried everything possible to get this game to run for more than 5 minutes without freezing.  The 5 minutes of of time that it did run, it ran at a perfect 60fps constant, but then would suddenly the graphics would just lock up.  Sound would play still, video not so much.  I would really love to play through this game in the future, but I don't have the GI tract to handle messing around with it at this point in time.


Update:  Well I fixed the issue and the reason for the freezing wasn't what I thought it was at all.  All I simply had to do was disable my Killer e2200 PCI-E Gigabit Ethernet Controller.  For some reason computers with this type of network card don't agree with bioshock infinite while the card is still active.  Wasn't a big deal disabling the NIC anyway for me since I use wireless in my house.  All those hours of headaches with such an easy and simple fix.

reviewText:
One hell of a game! It's one of those rare games that hooks you from the very beginning, and goes all the way in creating an immersive setting and narrative. Needless to say that these are the central elements of this game. The flying city of Columbia is visually stunning, and the storyline is intense and intriguing. Prepare to have your jaw dropped every once in a while, due to an ingenius plot twist (and prepare to be mind-blown in the end!). As in every Bioshock, Infinite will provide you with brainfood in terms of an in-dept analysis of political ideals and the place of science in society. However, the storyline is more focused on the protagonists, compared to the previous games. Speaking of which, the main characters are wonderfully 'real', and you will develop a sense of care for them.
Surprisingly, I found the combat less interesting. Yes, it's fast-paced. Yes, it has all the features that made old-school shooters great. But I can't help but considering the battles an unnecessary obligation. But don't be disappointed; you'll have a lot of heartpounding shoot-outs, worthy of rememberance. It's just that looking around looking for bits and pieces of the multi-layered story is what makes this game really great.

In short: a masterpiece, in every sense of the word. This is hardly a game, it's pure art.

She helps you thoughout the game by throwing you money and ammo and also by picking locks. You really feel like these are real people and are really doing what they're doing. The ending will give you chills.\n\nThe DLC is even better. It connects this game to the first one by showing you the events that lead up to the fall of Rapture and also by answering many of the questons that the first Bioshock raised. In the DLC you dont get as much ammo and weapons that you get in the main game, and you need to use stealth in order to get by. Its just as dark and creepy as you remember.

reviewText: Bioshock Infinite is firstly a first person shooter, and secondly an entry in the Bioshock series. This makes the game feel different from previous titles in  the series, in both positive and negative ways. It has a similar feel to it aesthetic-wise, there are various audio logs in the game, you go from place to place while given various directives, and the whole thing is rather linear. You are accompanied through most of the game with your companinon Elizabeth, who thankfully cannot be damaged by enemies, or the game's difficulty would be (pardon the pun) Infintely harder.\n\nThe story of the game is  questionable however, it is not difficult to understand for the most part, except the last part of the game which leaves me wondering what the heck just happened?" I was shocked when I beat this game not because I was particularly blown away
date: but it was a sense of anger instead. I just went through all that to be given such a dissatistfying ending. I felt cheated. I probably wouldn't playthrough the game again
recommended: but it was still a half decent experience to go through. The environments and the overall feel of the game is very enjoyable
